/**
 * Training Splits Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const trainingGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'training',
  slug: 'training-splits',
  title: 'Training Splits',
  subtitle: "Stop wandering the gym confused",
  description: "Structured workout programs for different experience levels and schedules. No more random workouts.",
  icon: 'Calendar',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 5,
  tags: ['training', 'workout', 'gym', 'programming', 'splits'],
  relatedGuides: ['v-taper', 'core-neck', 'cardio'],
  productIds: ['creatine_mono'],
  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'training-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1534438327276-14e5300c3a48?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Athlete performing compound lift in gym',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'Why Your Split Matters',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Walking into the gym without a plan is like going to the grocery store hungryâ€”you'll make bad decisions and leave unsatisfied.

---

## The Problem

Most guys either:

- Do random exercises they saw on Instagram
- Hit chest and arms every day, ignoring everything else
- Overcomplicate with 6-day PPL splits when they can barely make it 3x/week
- Follow a pro bodybuilder's routine when they've been lifting for 6 months

## The Fix

Choose a split that matches your:

- **Available training days** â€” Be realistic
- **Experience level** â€” Beginners need less volume
- **Recovery capacity** â€” Sleep, stress, nutrition all matter
- **Goals** â€” Strength vs hypertrophy vs both

Then stick with it for at least 8-12 weeks before changing anything.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'gym-planning',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571019614242-c5c5dee9f50b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Athlete writing workout plan',
          caption: 'A written plan is the difference between progress and spinning wheels',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'fundamentals',
      title: 'Training Fundamentals (All Splits)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Before we get into splits, these principles apply to everything:

---

## 1. Progressive Overload

You must increase weight, reps, or sets over time. If you're lifting the same weight for the same reps month after month, you're not growing.

## 2. Volume Matters

| Weekly Sets Per Muscle | Effect |
|------------------------|--------|
| **< 10 sets** | Probably not enough for growth |
| **10-20 sets** | Hypertrophy sweet spot |
| **> 20 sets** | Diminishing returns |

## 3. Intensity (Effort)

Most sets should be within 1-3 reps of failure. If you could do 5 more reps, you're not working hard enough.

## 4. Recovery

Muscles grow when you rest, not when you lift:

- Sleep 7-9 hours
- Eat enough protein
- Take rest days seriously

## 5. Consistency > Perfection

A 3-day routine done consistently beats a 6-day routine you keep missing. Pick something sustainable.`,
      tips: [
        'Track your liftsâ€”what gets measured gets managed',
        'Deload every 4-6 weeks (reduce volume or intensity)',
        'Sleep is anabolic. 6 hours is not enough.',
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'full-body',
      title: 'Full Body Split (3 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Best For:**
- Beginners (first 6-12 months)
- Busy schedules (only 3 gym days)
- Coming back after time off

---

## Why It Works

- High frequency per muscle (3x/week)
- More practice with compounds
- Easy to schedule
- Excellent for building foundation

---

## Sample Week

| Day | Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|-----|----------|-------------|
| **Monday** | | |
| | Squat | 3x8-10 |
| | Bench Press | 3x8-10 |
| | Barbell Row | 3x8-10 |
| | Overhead Press | 3x10-12 |
| | Bicep Curls | 2x12-15 |
| **Wednesday** | | |
| | Deadlift | 3x5 |
| | Incline DB Press | 3x10-12 |
| | Lat Pulldown | 3x10-12 |
| | Leg Press | 3x12-15 |
| | Tricep Pushdowns | 2x12-15 |
| **Friday** | | |
| | Squat | 3x8-10 |
| | Overhead Press | 3x8-10 |
| | Pull-Ups | 3xMax |
| | Romanian Deadlift | 3x10-12 |
| | Face Pulls | 3x15-20 |

---

## Progression

Add 5 lbs to lower body lifts and 2.5 lbs to upper body lifts each session when you complete all reps.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'squat-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1566241142559-40e1dab266c6?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Proper barbell squat form demonstration',
          caption: 'Squat: The king of lower body exercises',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'bench-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571019613454-1cb2f99b2d8b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Proper bench press form demonstration',
          caption: 'Bench Press: Retract scapula, arch back, feet planted',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'upper-lower',
      title: 'Upper/Lower Split (4 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Best For:**
- Intermediate lifters (1+ years)
- Those with 4 consistent gym days
- Balanced development focus

---

## Why It Works

- Good frequency (2x per muscle per week)
- Better recovery than PPL
- More volume per session than full body
- Flexible scheduling

---

## Sample Week

### Upper A (Monday)

| Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|----------|-------------|
| Bench Press | 4x6-8 |
| Barbell Row | 4x6-8 |
| Overhead Press | 3x8-10 |
| Pull-Ups | 3x8-12 |
| Lateral Raises | 3x15-20 |
| Tricep Work | 3x10-12 |

### Lower A (Tuesday)

| Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|----------|-------------|
| Squat | 4x6-8 |
| Romanian Deadlift | 3x8-10 |
| Leg Press | 3x10-12 |
| Leg Curl | 3x10-12 |
| Calf Raises | 4x15-20 |

### Upper B (Thursday)

| Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|----------|-------------|
| Overhead Press | 4x6-8 |
| Weighted Pull-Ups | 4x6-8 |
| Incline DB Press | 3x10-12 |
| Cable Rows | 3x10-12 |
| Face Pulls | 3x15-20 |
| Bicep Curls | 3x10-12 |

### Lower B (Friday)

| Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|----------|-------------|
| Deadlift | 3x5 |
| Front Squat | 3x8-10 |
| Walking Lunges | 3x10/leg |
| Leg Curl | 3x10-12 |
| Calf Raises | 4x15-20 |

---

**Notes:**
- Day A = heavier, Day B = moderate weight, more reps
- Rest at least one day between training the same muscles`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'deadlift-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598268030450-7a476f602e5c?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Proper deadlift form demonstration',
          caption: 'Deadlift: Hinge at hips, flat back, drive through heels',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'pullup-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598971639058-fab3c3109a00?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Proper pull-up form demonstration',
          caption: 'Pull-Up: Full extension, chest to bar, control the negative',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'ppl',
      title: 'Push/Pull/Legs Split (6 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Best For:**
- Intermediate to advanced (2+ years)
- Those with 5-6 gym days available
- Maximum volume and frequency goals

---

## Why It Works

- High frequency (2x per muscle per week)
- High volume per session
- Clear organization
- Most popular split for bodybuilding

---

## The Structure

| Day | Focus | Key Muscles |
|-----|-------|-------------|
| **Push A** | Heavy compounds | Chest, Shoulders, Triceps |
| **Pull A** | Heavy compounds | Back, Biceps, Rear Delts |
| **Legs A** | Heavy compounds | Quads, Hamstrings, Calves |
| **Push B** | Volume focus | Same muscles, different angles |
| **Pull B** | Volume focus | Same muscles, different angles |
| **Legs B** | Volume focus | Same muscles, different emphasis |

---

## Sample Push Day

| Exercise | Sets x Reps | Notes |
|----------|-------------|-------|
| Bench Press | 4x6-8 | Main compound |
| Overhead Press | 3x8-10 | Secondary compound |
| Incline DB Press | 3x10-12 | Upper chest focus |
| Lateral Raises | 4x15-20 | Side delt isolation |
| Tricep Dips | 3x8-12 | Compound tricep |
| Cable Pushdowns | 3x12-15 | Isolation finisher |

---

> **Warning:** This is a lot of volume. If you're not sleeping 8+ hours and eating 1g/lb protein, you won't recover properly.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'ohp-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1541534741688-6078c6bfb5c5?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Proper overhead press form demonstration',
          caption: 'Overhead Press: Brace core, press straight up, head through at top',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'lateral-raise',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1581009146145-b5ef050c149a?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Athlete performing dumbbell exercises',
          caption: 'Lateral Raise: Slight bend in elbows, lead with pinkies',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'bro-split',
      title: 'Bro Split (5 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `## The Classic

| Day | Focus |
|-----|-------|
| Monday | Chest |
| Tuesday | Back |
| Wednesday | Shoulders |
| Thursday | Arms |
| Friday | Legs |

---

## The Truth

The bro split is often mocked as "suboptimal" because each muscle only gets hit once per week.

Science says 2x per week frequency is better for hypertrophy.

---

## But Here's the Thing

If you've been training for years and want maximum volume per session, or if it's the only split you'll stick to consistently, it can still work.

### When It Makes Sense

- Advanced lifters who need 15-20+ sets per muscle
- Those who enjoy destroying one muscle group per session
- People who've tried other splits and prefer this

### When It Doesn't

- Beginners (you don't need that much volume)
- People who miss gym days frequently
- Natural lifters who benefit from frequency

---

## The Compromise

If you like the bro split style, consider hitting each muscle 1.5x per week:

- Chest + Triceps
- Back + Biceps
- Shoulders + Legs (light)
- Arms + Rear Delts
- Legs (heavy)`,
    },
    {
      id: 'exercise-selection',
      title: 'Choosing the Right Exercises',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Not all exercises are equal. Here's how to prioritize:

---

## Tier 1: Compound Movements (Build Your Foundation)

These should make up 60-70% of your training:

| Movement Pattern | Exercises |
|------------------|-----------|
| **Squat** | Back Squat, Front Squat, Goblet Squat |
| **Hinge** | Deadlift, RDL, Good Morning |
| **Horizontal Push** | Bench Press, DB Press, Push-Ups |
| **Horizontal Pull** | Barbell Row, DB Row, Cable Row |
| **Vertical Push** | Overhead Press, DB Shoulder Press |
| **Vertical Pull** | Pull-Ups, Lat Pulldown, Chin-Ups |

---

## Tier 2: Compound Accessories

- Lunges, leg press, RDLs
- Dips, incline press
- Face pulls, rear delt work
- Curl and tricep compound movements

## Tier 3: Isolation (Target Weaknesses)

- Lateral raises (for V-taper)
- Bicep curls (for arm peak)
- Tricep extensions (for arm size)
- Leg curls/extensions (for leg detail)
- Calf raises (for calf size)

---

> **The Mistake:** Building your routine around cable machines and isolation exercises. These are supplements to compounds, not replacements.`,
      tips: [
        'Master form on compounds before going heavy',
        'Isolations are for lagging body parts',
        'If short on time, cut isolations first, never compounds',
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'row-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1603287681836-b174ce5074c2?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Athlete performing back exercises',
          caption: 'Barbell Row: 45-degree torso, pull to lower chest',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'rep-ranges',
      title: 'Rep Ranges and What They Do',
      humorLevel: 'low',
      content: `Different rep ranges serve different purposes:

---

## The Ranges

| Reps | Focus | Best For |
|------|-------|----------|
| **1-5** | Strength | Compounds (squat, bench, deadlift) |
| **6-12** | Hypertrophy | Most trainingâ€”the sweet spot |
| **12-20+** | Metabolic/Pump | Small muscles, finishing sets |

---

## The Reality

Muscles grow across all rep ranges when taken close to failure.

The "6-12 for hypertrophy" rule is a guideline, not a law.

## Practical Application

| Exercise Type | Rep Range |
|---------------|-----------|
| **Compounds** | 5-10 reps |
| **Secondary compounds** | 8-12 reps |
| **Isolations** | 10-20 reps |

Mix it up within these guidelines for variety.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'progression',
      title: 'How to Progress',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `If you're not progressing, you're not growing. Here's how to ensure constant improvement:

---

## Method 1: Linear Progression (Beginners)

Add weight every session:

| Week | Bench Press |
|------|-------------|
| 1 | 135 x 3x8 |
| 2 | 140 x 3x8 |
| 3 | 145 x 3x8 |
| 4 | 150 x 3x8 |

Continue until you stall.

---

## Method 2: Double Progression (Intermediate)

Work within a rep range, increase weight when you hit the top:

| Week | Weight x Sets x Reps |
|------|---------------------|
| 1 | 185 x 3x8 |
| 2 | 185 x 3x9 |
| 3 | 185 x 3x10 |
| 4 | 190 x 3x8 (restart) |

---

## Method 3: Volume Progression (Advanced)

Keep weight same, add sets:

| Week | Sets |
|------|------|
| 1 | 3 sets |
| 2 | 4 sets |
| 3 | 5 sets |
| 4 | Deload |

---

## When You Stall

1. Check sleep and nutrition first
2. Deload (reduce volume/intensity for 1 week)
3. Try a different rep range or exercise variation
4. Accept that progress slows after the beginner phase`,
    },
    {
      id: 'choosing-split',
      title: 'Which Split Should You Choose?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The best split is the one you'll actually do consistently. Here's the decision tree:

---

## How many days can you REALISTICALLY train per week?

| Days Available | Recommended Split |
|----------------|-------------------|
| **3 Days** | Full Body |
| **4 Days** | Upper/Lower |
| **5 Days** | Upper/Lower/Upper/Lower/Full or modified PPL |
| **6 Days** | PPL (Push/Pull/Legs 2x) |

---

## Quick Guide

### 3 Days â†’ Full Body
- Best bang for buck with limited time
- Perfect for beginners

### 4 Days â†’ Upper/Lower
- Great balance of volume and recovery
- Good for most intermediates

### 5 Days â†’ Flexible
- More flexibility
- Good volume and frequency

### 6 Days â†’ PPL
- Maximum volume and frequency
- Requires excellent recovery
- Advanced or great genetics

---

> **Be Honest With Yourself:** If you're planning a 6-day split but realistically make it 3-4 times per week, you're doing yourself a disservice. A 4-day split done consistently beats a 6-day split done randomly.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono'],
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's what to do:

---

## Step 1: Choose Your Split

Based on your available training days and experience level. When in doubt, go with fewer days and build up.

## Step 2: Write It Down

Physically write or type your routine. Every exercise, sets, reps, and rest periods.

## Step 3: Track Every Workout

Use an app or notebook. Record weight x reps for every set.

## Step 4: Progress Each Session

Add weight, reps, or sets whenever possible. If you completed all prescribed reps, increase something next time.

## Step 5: Stick With It

**Minimum 8-12 weeks before changing programs.**

Program hopping is one of the biggest gains killers.

## Step 6: Deload When Needed

Every 4-6 weeks, take a lighter week. This isn't weaknessâ€”it's smart programming.

---

> The gym is simple: show up, lift more than last time, recover, repeat. Don't overcomplicate it.`,
    },
  ],
};

   158â†’      title: 'Neck Training Program',
   159â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   160â†’      content: `Here's a progressive neck training protocol:

   190â†’    {
   191â†’      id: 'core-fundamentals',
   192â†’      title: 'Core: Beyond Crunches',
   193â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   194â†’      content: `Your core is more than abs. It's the entire trunk stabilization system:
   195â†’
   196â†’**Core Functions:**
   197â†’1. **Anti-Extension** â€” Preventing back from arching (planks, ab wheel)

   216â†’      content: `Forget endless crunches. These exercises actually build a strong core:

   237â†’
   238â†’**The Vacuum:**

   244â†’      tips: [
   245â†’        'Ab wheel is brutally effectiveâ€”start from knees',

   247â†’        'Side planks should be felt in obliques, not hip'
   248â†’      ],
   249â†’    },
   250â†’    {
   251â†’      id: 'core-programming',
   252â†’      title: 'Core Training Program',
   253â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   254â†’      content: `Core can be trained frequently because the muscles recover fast:
   255â†’
   256â†’**Option 1: Dedicated Core Days (2-3x/Week)**

   258â†’

   260â†’- Hanging Leg Raises: 3x10-15

   268â†’- Day 2: Leg Raises + Side Planks

   275â†’- Superset Squats with Dead Bug
   276â†’- Efficient use of time
   277â†’
   278â†’**Volume Guidelines:**
   279â†’- 6-12 sets of direct core work per week
   280â†’- Compounds (squats, deadlifts) also train core
   281â†’- Don't overthinkâ€”consistency matters more than perfection
   282â†’
   283â†’**Daily Vacuum Practice:**
   284â†’- Morning, before eating: 5-10 vacuums, 15-30 sec holds
   285â†’- This is cumulativeâ€”daily practice shrinks waist appearance`,
   286â†’    },
   287â†’    {
   288â†’      id: 'obliques-warning',
   289â†’      title: 'A Note on Oblique Training',
   290â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   291â†’      content: `Here's something most people get wrong:
   292â†’
   293â†’**The Goal:**
   294â†’A narrow waist and visible V-taper.

   299â†’**The Problem:**

   301â†’
   302â†’**The Solution:**
   303â†’- Skip heavy direct oblique work entirely
   304â†’- Obliques get enough stimulus from:
   305â†’  - Compound lifts (squats, deadlifts)
   306â†’  - Anti-rotation work (Pallof press)
   307â†’  - Side planks (isometric, not hypertrophy-focused)
   308â†’
   309â†’**For Most Guys:**
   310â†’Never do weighted side bends. Never do heavy wood chops. Your obliques are probably already developed enough from other training. Adding size to them will widen your waist.
   311â†’
   312â†’**Exception:**
   313â†’If you're a competitive athlete who needs rotational power (golfer, baseball player), train obliques. For aesthetics? Skip the heavy stuff.`,
   314â†’      warnings: [
   315â†’        'Weighted side bends can increase waist width',
   316â†’        'Obliques are often overdeveloped relative to needs',
   317â†’        'V-taper requires a narrow waist, not thick obliques'
   318â†’      ],
   319â†’    },
   320â†’    {
   321â†’      id: 'action-plan',
   322â†’      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   323â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   324â†’      content: `Here's your complete core + neck upgrade plan:
   325â†’
   326â†’**Week 1-4: Foundation**
   327â†’- Neck: Manual resistance, 3x per week, 5 min each
   328â†’- Core: Ab wheel + leg raises + side plank, 2x per week, 10 min each
   329â†’- Vacuum: Daily, 5 holds of 20 seconds
   330â†’
   331â†’**Week 5-8: Build**
   332â†’- Neck: Add light weight (5-10 lbs), 3x per week
   333â†’- Core: Progress to harder variations, add Pallof press
   334â†’- Vacuum: 10 holds of 30 seconds
   335â†’
   336â†’**Week 9+: Progress**
   337â†’- Neck: Progressive overload, 2-3x per week, working toward 25+ lbs
   338â†’- Core: Full routine, 2x per week, focus on getting stronger
   339â†’- Vacuum: Maintenance, daily habit
   340â†’
   341â†’**Expected Results:**
   342â†’- Neck: 0.5-1 inch growth in first 2-3 months
   343â†’- Core: Visible improvement in 4-6 weeks (if diet is right)
   344â†’- Posture: Noticeable improvement in 2-4 weeks
   345â†’
   346â†’**The Payoff:**
   347â†’These are two of the highest-ROI muscle groups you can train. Minimal time investment, maximum visual and functional return. Don't skip them.`,
   348â†’      products: ['creatine_mono'],
   349â†’    },
   350â†’  ],
   351â†’};

/**
 * Core & Neck Training Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const coreNeckGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'core-neck',
  slug: 'core-neck-training',
  title: 'Core & Neck Training',
  subtitle: "The overlooked muscles that change everything",
  description: "Build a solid core for posture and a thick neck for masculine presence. Both are underrated game-changers.",
  icon: 'Target',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 6,
  tags: ['core', 'neck', 'posture', 'training', 'aesthetics'],
  relatedGuides: ['training', 'v-taper', 'body-fat'],
  productIds: ['creatine_mono'],
  forumCategory: 'height-frame',
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'Why Core and Neck Matter',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Two of the most overlooked muscle groups that have outsized impact on your appearance:

**The Neck:**
A thick neck makes your head look proportionate, adds masculinity, and completely changes how you're perceived. Think about the difference between a pencil neck and a football player neck. Night and day.

**The Core:**
Beyond aesthetics, a strong core improves posture, supports lifting heavy, and defines that V-taper from waist. Weak core = weak everything else.

Most guys skip both because:
- Neck training seems weird or unsafe
- Core work is boring (crunches in the corner)
- Neither is a "mirror muscle"

This is a mistake. Both are trainable, and both pay massive dividends.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'neck-benefits',
      title: 'Neck: The Masculine Multiplier',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `A thick neck is one of the most underrated aesthetic upgrades you can make:

**Visual Benefits:**
- Head looks proportionate to body
- Jawline appears stronger
- More masculine/dominant presence
- Fills out shirt collars
- Better photos from every angle

**Functional Benefits:**
- Reduced neck pain
- Better posture support
- Injury prevention (sports, accidents)
- Improved head position for mewing

**The Reality:**
Compare a skinny neck to a thick neck on the same person. It's a completely different look. Yet almost nobody trains it.

The neck is one of the fastest-growing muscle groups because most people have never trained it. You can add an inch to your neck in 2-3 months with consistent training.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'neck-anatomy',
      title: 'Neck Muscles to Train',
      humorLevel: 'low',
      content: `Understanding what you're training helps you train it better:

**Sternocleidomastoid (SCM)**
- The muscles on the front/sides of your neck
- Creates that "thick neck" look from the front
- Trained with neck curls and lateral flexion

**Trapezius (Upper Traps)**
- The muscles connecting neck to shoulders
- Creates width and thickness from behind
- Trained with shrugs and neck extensions

**Splenius (Deep Neck Extensors)**
- Muscles on the back of the neck
- Important for head position and posture
- Trained with neck extensions

**Scalenes**
- Side of neck, often tight from desk work
- Important for balanced development
- Trained with lateral neck flexion

**Training All Directions:**
The neck moves in four directions:
1. Flexion (chin to chest)
2. Extension (looking up)
3. Lateral flexion (ear to shoulder)
4. Rotation (turning head)

Train all of them for balanced development.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'neck-exercises',
      title: 'Neck Training Exercises',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Start with bodyweight, progress to resistance:

**Beginner: Manual Resistance (First 4 Weeks)**
Use your hands to provide resistance:

1. **Neck Curls (Flexion)**
   - Push forehead against palm
   - Resist and try to bring chin to chest
   - 3x10-15 each direction

2. **Neck Extensions**
   - Cup back of head with hands
   - Resist and try to look up
   - 3x10-15

3. **Lateral Flexion**
   - Hand on side of head
   - Resist and try to touch ear to shoulder
   - 3x10-15 each side

**Intermediate: Neck Harness/Plate (After 1 Month)**
1. **Weighted Neck Curls**
   - Lie face up on bench, head off edge
   - Hold plate on forehead
   - Curl chin to chest
   - 3x15-20

2. **Weighted Neck Extensions**
   - Lie face down on bench, head off edge
   - Plate on back of head (or neck harness)
   - Extend neck up
   - 3x15-20

3. **Neck Harness Extensions**
   - Best for progressive overload
   - Start light (5-10 lbs)
   - Build to 25-45+ lbs over months

**Advanced: Neck Curls Machine**
If your gym has one (rare), use it. Best equipment for neck training.`,
      tips: [
        'Start LIGHTâ€”the neck is sensitive and untrained',
        'Progress slowlyâ€”add 2.5-5 lbs per week max',
        'Avoid jerky movementsâ€”slow and controlled always'
      ],
      warnings: [
        'Never roll the neck under loadâ€”risk of injury',
        "Don't train to absolute failure on neck exercises",
        'Stop immediately if you feel any sharp pain'
      ],
    },
    {

      title: 'Neck Training Program',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's a progressive neck training protocol:

**Phase 1: Manual Resistance (Weeks 1-4)**
- Frequency: 3x per week
- Duration: 5 minutes at end of workout
- All four directions, 2 sets each

**Phase 2: Light Weight (Weeks 5-8)**
- Add 2.5-5 lb plates
- Frequency: 2-3x per week
- 2-3 sets of 15-20 reps each direction
- Focus on mind-muscle connection

**Phase 3: Progressive Overload (Weeks 9+)**
- Increase weight when you hit 25 reps easily
- Work up to 3-4 sets of 15-20 reps
- 2x per week is sufficient at this stage

**Weekly Volume:**
- 6-12 sets per week is plenty
- Don't overtrainâ€”neck recovers but can get sore easily
- Spread across 2-3 sessions

**Sample Session (10 Minutes):**
1. Neck Curls: 3x15-20
2. Neck Extensions: 3x15-20

      title: 'Core: Beyond Crunches',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your core is more than abs. It's the entire trunk stabilization system:

**Why This Matters:**
Crunches only train one function (spinal flexion). A complete core routine trains all four. This builds functional strength that transfers to:
- Better posture

**The Ab Visibility Truth:**

3. **Single-Arm Cable Rows** â€” Resist rotation while pulling

**Anti-Lateral Flexion:**
1. **Side Planks** â€” Basic but effective

**Hip Flexion:**

    {
      id: 'core-programming',
      title: 'Core Training Program',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Core can be trained frequently because the muscles recover fast:

**Option 1: Dedicated Core Days (2-3x/Week)**
Add 10-15 minutes of core work after upper body sessions:

- Ab Wheel Rollouts: 3x8-12
- Hanging Leg Raises: 3x10-15
- Pallof Press: 2x10-12 each side

**Option 2: Integrated (Every Session)**
Add 1-2 core exercises to every workout:

**Option 3: Supersetting**

**Volume Guidelines:**
- 6-12 sets of direct core work per week

**Daily Vacuum Practice:**

    {

      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Here's something most people get wrong:

**The Goal:**
A narrow waist and visible V-taper.

**The Mistake:**
Heavy weighted oblique exercises (side bends, wood chops with heavy weight).

**The Problem:**
Your obliques are muscles. If you train them with heavy resistance, they grow. Bigger obliques = wider waist. This is the opposite of what you want.

**The Solution:**
- Skip heavy direct oblique work entirely

  - Compound lifts (squats, deadlifts)
  - Anti-rotation work (Pallof press)

Never do weighted side bends. Never do heavy wood chops. Your obliques are probably already developed enough from other training. Adding size to them will widen your waist.

If you're a competitive athlete who needs rotational power (golfer, baseball player), train obliques. For aesthetics? Skip the heavy stuff.`,

   402â†’**Step 6: Adjust Based on Results**
   403â†’- Losing too fast? Reduce cardio, add food
   404â†’- Not losing? Add steps or one session
   405â†’- Feeling exhausted? More LISS, less HIIT
   406â†’
   407â†’**Remember:**
   408â†’Cardio is a tool, not the goal. Use it strategically. More is not always better. Diet is the primary driver of fat lossâ€”cardio is the accelerator, not the engine.`,
   409â†’    },
   410â†’  ],
   411â†’};
   412â†’

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

file.content:
/**
 * Cardio Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const cardioGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'cardio',
  slug: 'cardio-training',
  title: 'Cardio Training',
  subtitle: "Not just for losing fatâ€”but also for losing fat",
  description: "Strategic cardio for fat loss, conditioning, and health without killing your gains. Find the right balance.",
  icon: 'Heart',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 7,
  tags: ['cardio', 'fat-loss', 'conditioning', 'heart-health'],
  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'diet'],
  productIds: [],
  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'cardio-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571008887538-b36bb32f4571?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Cardio training and running',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Cardio Debate',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `There are two extreme camps on cardio:

**Camp 1: "Cardio kills gains"**
- Never steps on a treadmill
- Gets winded walking up stairs
- Can bench 300 but can't jog a mile

**Camp 2: "Cardio is everything"**
- Runs marathons
- Skinny-fat physique
- No muscle to show for their efforts

**The Truth:**
Both are wrong. Cardio is a tool. Like any tool, it's about how you use it.

Used correctly, cardio:
- Accelerates fat loss
- Improves heart health
- Increases work capacity
- Enhances recovery between sets
- Doesn't destroy muscle gains

The key is knowing when, how much, and what type.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'cardio-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1538805060514-97d9cc17730c?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Running and cardio training',
          caption: 'Cardio is a toolâ€”use it strategically',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'fat-loss-math',
      title: 'Cardio and Fat Loss: The Math',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's get the fundamentals clear:

**The Equation:**
Fat Loss = Calories Out > Calories In

Cardio increases "calories out." That's it. No magic.

**The Numbers:**
- 30 min walking (3.5 mph): ~150 calories
- 30 min jogging (5 mph): ~300 calories
- 30 min cycling (moderate): ~250 calories
- 30 min HIIT: ~300-400 calories

**The Reality Check:**
A single Snickers bar is 250 calories. You'd need 30 minutes of jogging to burn that off. This is why diet is the primary lever for fat loss, not cardio.

**Where Cardio Helps:**
1. Creating a bigger deficit without eating less
2. Allowing more food flexibility while still losing
3. Breaking plateaus when diet is already dialed in
4. General health benefits beyond fat loss

**The Mistake:**
Using cardio to "earn" food. This creates an unhealthy relationship and usually results in eating more than you burned.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'liss',
      title: 'LISS: Low Intensity Steady State',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `LISS is exactly what it sounds like: low intensity, sustained duration.

**Examples:**
- Walking (incline or flat)
- Light cycling
- Elliptical at conversational pace
- Swimming easy laps

**Heart Rate Zone:**
Zone 2 cardio: 60-70% of max heart rate
(Roughly: 220 - your age = max, then multiply by 0.6-0.7)

**Benefits:**
- Minimal interference with lifting
- Easy to recover from
- Can do fasted without issues
- Burns primarily fat for fuel
- Low impact on joints
- Can do daily if needed

**Protocol:**
- Duration: 20-45 minutes
- Frequency: 2-5x per week depending on goals
- When: Morning fasted, post-workout, or separate session

**The Walking Hack:**
10,000 steps per day burns an extra 300-500 calories. This is NEAT (non-exercise activity thermogenesis) and is often more effective than formal cardio because it's sustainable and doesn't feel like "exercise."`,
      tips: [
        'Walking is underratedâ€”10K steps/day is a game changer',
        'Incline walking burns more than flat without adding impact',
        'Can do LISS daily without recovery issues'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'liss-walking',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1476480862126-209bfaa8edc8?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Walking for cardio and fat loss',
          caption: 'Walking: The most sustainable cardio',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'hiit',
      title: 'HIIT: High Intensity Interval Training',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `HIIT alternates between intense effort and rest periods.

**Examples:**
- Sprints (track, bike, rower)
- Battle ropes
- Burpees/jump squats intervals
- Cycling sprints

**Structure:**
- 20-30 seconds max effort
- 60-90 seconds recovery
- Repeat 6-10 rounds
- Total: 15-25 minutes

**Benefits:**
- Time efficient (done in 20 minutes)
- Burns more calories per minute than LISS
- EPOC effect (elevated metabolism post-workout)
- Improves anaerobic conditioning
- More engaging than steady state

**Drawbacks:**
- Harder to recover from
- Can interfere with leg days
- Higher injury risk if form breaks down
- Not sustainable daily
- Actually requires max effort (most people don't go hard enough)

**Frequency:**
- 1-3 sessions per week max
- Not on leg day or day before
- Requires 48+ hours recovery

**The Truth About HIIT:**
Most people's "HIIT" is really "medium intensity interval training." True HIIT is incredibly demandingâ€”you should feel like dying after the work intervals. If you can do more than 20-25 minutes, you're not going hard enough.`,
      warnings: [
        'True HIIT is brutalâ€”most people do it wrong',
        'Limit to 2-3x/week to allow recovery',
        'Not recommended for complete beginners'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'hiit-training',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1549060279-7e168fcee0c2?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'High intensity interval training',
          caption: 'HIIT: Maximum effort, minimum time',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'liss-vs-hiit',
      title: 'LISS vs HIIT: Which Is Better?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The eternal debate. Here's the breakdown:

**LISS Wins When:**
- You're already doing intense lifting 4-6x/week
- Recovery is limited (sleep, stress, nutrition issues)
- Joint health is a concern
- You need daily cardio for deficit
- You're a beginner to cardio

**HIIT Wins When:**
- You're short on time
- You only need 1-2 cardio sessions per week
- Your lifting program is less demanding
- You want conditioning benefits beyond fat loss
- You're already fit and recover well

**The Optimal Approach:**
Combine both:
- 2-4x LISS per week (walking, incline, cycling)
- 1-2x HIIT per week (if recovery allows)
- Adjust based on how you feel and progress

**The Research:**
For pure fat loss, total calories burned matters mostâ€”not the type of cardio. LISS and HIIT are roughly equivalent when total calorie expenditure is matched.

Choose based on:
1. What you'll actually do consistently
2. What you can recover from
3. What fits your schedule`,
    },
    {
      id: 'preserving-muscle',
      title: 'Cardio Without Killing Gains',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `The fear of "losing gains" to cardio is overblown. But there are real considerations:

**What Actually Hurts Gains:**
1. Too much cardio volume (hours per week)
2. Running long distances (marathon training)
3. HIIT on leg days or day before
4. Cardio in a severe calorie deficit without adequate protein
5. Prioritizing cardio over lifting

**What Doesn't Hurt Gains:**
1. Walking (any amount)
2. 20-30 min LISS 3-5x/week
3. Cycling (often even complements leg training)
4. 1-2 HIIT sessions per week with recovery
5. General activity throughout the day

**The Protocol for Muscle Preservation:**
1. Lift first, cardio second (always)
2. Separate lifting and cardio by 6+ hours if possible
3. Keep HIIT away from leg training
4. Eat adequate protein (1g/lb)
5. Keep cardio modestâ€”enough for goals, not more

**The Truth:**
Moderate cardio (3-5 hours per week) does not meaningfully impair muscle growth when nutrition and lifting are on point. The guys who lose muscle to cardio are usually:
- Doing way too much cardio
- Not eating enough
- Not lifting with enough intensity`,
    },
    {
      id: 'fasted-cardio',
      title: 'Fasted Cardio: Does It Work?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The idea: do cardio before eating to burn more fat.

**The Theory:**
- Glycogen is low after sleeping
- Body will use fat for fuel
- More fat burned during the session

**The Research:**
- Yes, more fat is burned DURING fasted cardio
- BUT total 24-hour fat oxidation is the same
- Your body compensates later in the day
- Overall fat loss is determined by total deficit, not timing

**When Fasted Cardio Makes Sense:**
1. You prefer it (some people have more energy fasted)
2. Scheduling (morning before work is your only option)
3. You don't like eating before exercise
4. LISS specifically (HIIT fasted can be rough)

**When It Doesn't:**
1. You feel weak or dizzy fasted
2. You're doing HIIT or intense training
3. Performance matters (fed = better performance)
4. You have blood sugar issues

**The Bottom Line:**
Fasted vs fed cardio is personal preference. Total calorie balance matters more than timing. Do whatever helps you stay consistent.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'step-count',
      title: 'The Daily Step Count Approach',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Forget formal cardio sessions. Here's a simpler approach:

**The Concept:**
Track daily steps instead of scheduled cardio. Walking is the most sustainable, lowest-impact form of movement.

**The Target:**
- Minimum: 7,000 steps/day
- Good: 10,000 steps/day
- Optimal: 12,000-15,000 steps/day

**The Math:**
- 10,000 steps â‰ˆ 5 miles â‰ˆ 400-500 calories
- That's 2,800-3,500 extra calories per week
- Roughly 0.5-1 lb of fat loss potential

**How to Get Steps:**
1. Walk during phone calls
2. Park farther away
3. Take stairs always
4. Walking meetings
5. Post-meal walks (also helps blood sugar)
6. Dedicated 30-45 min walk daily
7. Walking desk/treadmill desk

**Why This Works:**
- Doesn't feel like exercise
- Easy to recover from
- Fits into daily life
- Sustainable long-term
- Burns significant calories over time

**For Cutting:**
Many people find step count + lifting more sustainable than formal cardio. Walking is the secret weapon.`,
      tips: [
        'Get a step-tracking watch or use your phone',
        'Morning walks start the day with momentum',
        'Post-dinner walks improve digestion and sleep'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'programming',
      title: 'Cardio Programming by Goal',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's how to structure cardio based on your current goal:

**Goal: Fat Loss (Primary)**
- Steps: 10,000-12,000 daily
- LISS: 20-30 min, 3-4x/week
- HIIT: 1x/week optional
- Total: 3-5 hours including walking

**Goal: Maintenance/Health**
- Steps: 8,000-10,000 daily
- LISS: 20-30 min, 2-3x/week
- HIIT: 1x/week
- Total: 2-3 hours

**Goal: Building Muscle (Minimize Cardio)**
- Steps: 7,000-10,000 daily
- LISS: 15-20 min, 2x/week
- HIIT: 0-1x/week
- Total: 1-2 hours

**Goal: Athletic Performance**
- Steps: As needed
- Sport-specific conditioning
- HIIT: 2-3x/week
- LISS: Active recovery days
- Total: 3-5 hours

**Adjusting:**
- Scale slowing? Add 1 session or 2,000 steps
- Feeling overtrained? Remove HIIT first
- Recovery suffering? Reduce intensity before frequency`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's how to implement cardio effectively:

**Step 1: Track Current Activity**
Wear a tracker for a week. See your baseline steps and activity.

**Step 2: Set Your Target**
Based on your goal (see previous section). Start conservative and build.

**Step 3: Prioritize Walking**
Get to 10,000 steps before adding formal cardio. This is the foundation.

**Step 4: Add Formal Cardio If Needed**
Only if steps + diet isn't creating enough deficit, add:
- LISS first (2-3x/week, 20-30 min)
- HIIT second (1x/week, 15-20 min)

**Step 5: Protect Your Lifting**
- Never do cardio before lifting
- Keep HIIT away from leg days
- Eat adequately (don't stack deficit + excess cardio)

**Step 6: Adjust Based on Results**
- Losing too fast? Reduce cardio, add food
- Not losing? Add steps or one session
- Feeling exhausted? More LISS, less HIIT

**Remember:**
Cardio is a tool, not the goal. Use it strategically. More is not always better. Diet is the primary driver of fat lossâ€”cardio is the accelerator, not the engine.`,
    },
  ],
};

content.content:
1â†’/**
     2â†’ * Diet & Nutrition Guide
     3â†’ * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
     4â†’ */
     5â†’
     6â†’import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';
     7â†’
     8â†’export const dietGuide: Guide = {
     9â†’  id: 'diet',
    10â†’  slug: 'diet-nutrition',
    11â†’  title: 'Diet & Nutrition',
    12â†’  subtitle: "You can't out-train a bad diet",
    13â†’  description: "The fundamentals of eating for aesthetics. Protein, calories, and what actually matters vs what doesn't.",
    14â†’  icon: 'Utensils',
    15â†’  humorLevel: 'medium',
    16â†’  estimatedReadTime: 15,
    17â†’  order: 8,
    18â†’  tags: ['nutrition', 'diet', 'protein', 'calories', 'macros'],
    19â†’  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'v-taper'],
    20â†’  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'collagen_peptides', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate'],
    21â†’  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
    22â†’  heroMedia: {
    23â†’    id: 'diet-hero',
    24â†’    type: 'image',
    25â†’    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1490645935967-10de6ba17061?w=1200&q=80',
    26â†’    alt: 'Healthy meal prep and nutrition',
    27â†’    placement: 'hero',
    28â†’  },
    29â†’  sections: [
    30â†’    {
    31â†’      id: 'intro',
    32â†’      title: 'The Foundation of Everything',
    33â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    34â†’      content: `Your physique is built in the kitchen, revealed in the gym.
    35â†’
    36â†’You can train perfectly, but if your nutrition is garbage:
    37â†’- You won't build muscle efficiently
    38â†’- You won't lose fat predictably
    39â†’- You'll look the same in 6 months
    40â†’
    41â†’**The Good News:**
    42â†’Nutrition is simpler than the internet makes it seem. Most of the complexity is unnecessary.
    43â†’
    44â†’**What Actually Matters (80% of results):**
    45â†’1. Total calories (energy balance)
    46â†’2. Protein intake
    47â†’3. Food quality (mostly)
    48â†’4. Consistency
    49â†’
    50â†’**What Barely Matters (20% optimization):**
    51â†’- Meal timing
    52â†’- Specific food choices within reason
    53â†’- Supplement stacks beyond basics
    54â†’- Nutrient timing around workouts
    55â†’
    56â†’Let's cover the 80% first.`,
    57â†’      media: [
    58â†’        {
    59â†’          id: 'diet-intro',
    60â†’          type: 'image',
    61â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1498837167922-ddd27525d352?w=800&q=80',
    62â†’          alt: 'Healthy food and nutrition',
    63â†’          caption: 'Your physique is built in the kitchen',
    64â†’          placement: 'inline',
    65â†’        },
    66â†’      ],
    67â†’    },
    68â†’    {
    69â†’      id: 'calories',
    70â†’      title: 'Calories: The Master Variable',
    71â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    72â†’      content: `Everything else is secondary to energy balance.
    73â†’
    74â†’**The Basic Math:**
    75â†’- Calories In > Calories Out = Weight Gain
    76â†’- Calories In < Calories Out = Weight Loss
    77â†’- Calories In = Calories Out = Maintenance
    78â†’
    79â†’**Finding Your Maintenance:**
    80â†’Method 1: Calculator estimate
    81â†’- TDEE calculator gives starting point
    82â†’- Typically 14-17 x bodyweight (in lbs)
    83â†’- Active people higher, sedentary lower
    84â†’
    85â†’Method 2: Track and observe
    86â†’- Eat the same for 2 weeks
    87â†’- Track weight daily, average weekly
    88â†’- Stable = maintenance. Rising = surplus. Dropping = deficit.
    89â†’
    90â†’**Setting Your Target:**
    91â†’
    92â†’| Goal | Calorie Target |
    93â†’|------|---------------|
    94â†’| Fat Loss | Maintenance - 300-500 |
    95â†’| Maintenance | TDEE |
    96â†’| Lean Bulk | Maintenance + 200-300 |
    97â†’| Standard Bulk | Maintenance + 400-500 |
    98â†’
    99â†’**The Mistake:**
   100â†’Going too aggressive. A 1000 calorie deficit sounds fast but leads to muscle loss, metabolic adaptation, and binges. Slow and steady wins.`,
   101â†’      products: ['food_scale'],
   102â†’      tips: [
   103â†’        'Use a food scale for accuracyâ€”eyeballing is notoriously wrong',
   104â†’        'Track for 2-4 weeks to learn your foods, then you can estimate',
   105â†’        'Weekly average matters more than daily fluctuations'
   106â†’      ],
   107â†’    },
   108â†’    {
   109â†’      id: 'protein',
   110â†’      title: 'Protein: The King of Macros',
   111â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   112â†’      content: `If you remember one thing from this guide: hit your protein.
   113â†’
   114â†’**Why Protein Is King:**
   115â†’- Builds and preserves muscle
   116â†’- Most satiating macro (keeps you full)
   117â†’- Highest thermic effect (burns calories to digest)
   118â†’- Hardest to store as fat
   119â†’
   120â†’**How Much:**
   121â†’- Minimum: 0.7g per pound of bodyweight
   122â†’- Optimal: 0.8-1g per pound of bodyweight
   123â†’- Upper limit: More than 1.2g/lb has no additional benefit
   124â†’
   125â†’**For a 180lb Guy:**
   126â†’- Minimum: 126g daily
   127â†’- Optimal: 144-180g daily
   128â†’
   129â†’**Best Protein Sources:**
   130â†’
   131â†’| Source | Protein per 100g |
   132â†’|--------|-----------------|
   133â†’| Chicken breast | 31g |
   134â†’| Lean beef | 26g |
   135â†’| Salmon | 25g |
   136â†’| Greek yogurt | 10g |
   137â†’| Eggs | 13g |
   138â†’| Cottage cheese | 11g |
   139â†’| Whey protein | 80g |
   140â†’
   141â†’**Hitting It Daily:**
   142â†’- Each meal should have a protein source
   143â†’- 30-50g per meal, 3-4 meals
   144â†’- Fill gaps with protein shakes if needed
   145â†’- Front-load protein earlier in day for satiety`,
   146â†’    },
   147â†’    {
   148â†’      id: 'carbs-fats',
   149â†’      title: 'Carbs and Fats: The Flexible Macros',
   150â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   151â†’      content: `After calories and protein, carbs and fats are flexible. Here's how to think about them:
   152â†’
   153â†’**Fats: The Minimum**
   154â†’- Never go below 0.3g/lb bodyweight
   155â†’- Fats are essential for hormones (testosterone)
   156â†’- Too low = hormone problems, brain fog, bad skin
   157â†’- For 180lb: minimum 54g fat daily
   158â†’
   159â†’**Carbs: The Performance Fuel**
   160â†’- Not "essential" but highly beneficial for training
   161â†’- Fill remaining calories after protein and fat
   162â†’- More carbs = better gym performance
   163â†’- Lower carbs = some people do better for fat loss
   164â†’
   165â†’**Setting Macros (Example: 180lb guy, 2500 calories)**
   166â†’
   167â†’Option 1: Moderate carb (recommended)
   168â†’- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
   169â†’- Fat: 80g (720 cal)
   170â†’- Carbs: 265g (1060 cal)
   171â†’
   172â†’Option 2: Lower carb
   173â†’- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
   174â†’- Fat: 100g (900 cal)
   175â†’- Carbs: 220g (880 cal)
   176â†’
   177â†’Option 3: Higher carb (athletic)
   178â†’- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
   179â†’- Fat: 60g (540 cal)
   180â†’- Carbs: 310g (1240 cal)
   181â†’
   182â†’**The Truth:**
   183â†’For most people, the exact ratio doesn't matter much. Hit protein, stay in your calorie range, and adjust carbs/fats based on preference and how you feel.`,
   184â†’    },
   185â†’    {
   186â†’      id: 'food-quality',
   187â†’      title: 'Food Quality: What to Actually Eat',
   188â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   189â†’      content: `Here's where things get simpler than the internet suggests:
   190â†’
   191â†’**The 80/20 Rule:**
   192â†’- 80% whole, minimally processed foods
   193â†’- 20% whatever you want
   194â†’
   195â†’This keeps you sane while getting results.
   196â†’
   197â†’**Whole Foods (Prioritize These):**
   198â†’
   199â†’**Proteins:**
   200â†’- Chicken, turkey, lean beef, fish
   201â†’- Eggs, Greek yogurt, cottage cheese
   202â†’- Whey/casein protein powder
   203â†’
   204â†’**Carbs:**
   205â†’- Rice, potatoes, oats
   206â†’- Fruits, vegetables
   207â†’- Whole grain bread/pasta
   208â†’
   209â†’**Fats:**
   210â†’- Olive oil, avocados
   211â†’- Nuts, seeds
   212â†’- Fatty fish (salmon)
   213â†’- Eggs
   214â†’
   215â†’**Minimize (Not Eliminate):**
   216â†’- Fried foods
   217â†’- Sugary snacks and drinks
   218â†’- Processed meats regularly
   219â†’- Alcohol (empty calories + lowers testosterone + disrupts sleep)
   220â†’
   221â†’**The Why:**
   222â†’Whole foods are more filling per calorie, have more micronutrients, and are harder to overeat. You can lose weight on junk food (calories are calories), but you'll be hungrier and less healthy.`,
   223â†’      media: [
   224â†’        {
   225â†’          id: 'whole-foods',
   226â†’          type: 'image',
   227â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1512621776951-a57141f2eefd?w=800&q=80',
   228â†’          alt: 'Whole foods and vegetables',
   229â†’          caption: '80% whole foods, 20% whatever you want',
   230â†’          placement: 'inline',
   231â†’        },
   232â†’      ],
   233â†’    },
   234â†’    {
   235â†’      id: 'meal-structure',
   236â†’      title: 'Meal Structure and Timing',
   237â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   238â†’      content: `Meal timing is overrated for results but matters for adherence and performance.
   239â†’
   240â†’**The Basics:**
   241â†’- Total daily intake matters more than timing
   242â†’- 3-5 meals per day works for most people
   243â†’- Don't overthink it
   244â†’
   245â†’**What Slightly Matters:**
   246â†’
   247â†’1. **Pre-Workout (1-2 hours before)**
   248â†’   - Carbs + protein = better performance
   249â†’   - Don't train completely fasted if you can help it
   250â†’   - Something > nothing
   251â†’
   252â†’2. **Post-Workout (within 2-3 hours)**
   253â†’   - Protein helps start recovery
   254â†’   - The "anabolic window" is way longer than old bro-science claimed
   255â†’   - Just eat normally, don't stress
   256â†’
   257â†’3. **Before Bed**
   258â†’   - Casein or slow protein can help overnight recovery
   259â†’   - Not essential, just nice
   260â†’
   261â†’**A Simple Day Structure:**
   262â†’
   263â†’- Breakfast: Protein + carbs + fats
   264â†’- Lunch: Protein + carbs + vegetables
   265â†’- Pre-workout: Light carbs + protein if needed
   266â†’- Dinner: Protein + carbs + vegetables
   267â†’- Optional snack: Protein if needed to hit target
   268â†’
   269â†’**Intermittent Fasting:**
   270â†’Some people like it. It doesn't burn more fat, but it can help control calories if you're bad at small meals. Personal preference.`,
   271â†’    },

   275â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   276â†’      content: `When cutting, everything matters a bit more:

   301â†’You can eat 500g of potatoes for the same calories as 50g of chips. Volume matters.

   307â†’4. Weekend binges (erases weekly deficit)
   308â†’5. Not tracking (guessing incorrectly)`,
   309â†’      tips: [

   318â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   319â†’      content: `Bulking done right builds muscle. Bulking done wrong just makes you fat.

   351â†’    },

   356â†’      content: `Most supplements are garbage. Here's what's worth your money:
   357â†’

   369â†’   - Not magic, just food in powder form
   370â†’
   371â†’3. **Vitamin D3**
   372â†’   - Most people are deficient

   374â†’   - Get blood work to confirm
   375â†’

   377â†’   - Anti-inflammatory

   379â†’   - 2-3g EPA/DHA daily
   380â†’
   381â†’**Tier 2: Situationally Useful**
   382â†’
   383â†’5. **Caffeine** â€” Performance boost (from coffee is fine)
   384â†’6. **Magnesium** â€” Most people are deficient, helps sleep
   385â†’7. **Collagen** â€” May help joints and skin

   392â†’- Testosterone boosters (don't work)

   395â†’**The Rule:**
   396â†’Get 95% of results from food. Use supplements to fill gaps, not replace meals.`,
   397â†’      products: ['creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate', 'collagen_peptides'],
   398â†’    },
   399â†’    {
   400â†’      id: 'practical',
   401â†’      title: 'Practical Meal Prep',
   402â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   403â†’      content: `Knowing what to eat is useless if you don't actually do it. Here's how:
   404â†’
   405â†’**The Basics of Meal Prep:**
   406â†’1. Pick 2-3 protein sources
   407â†’2. Pick 2-3 carb sources
   408â†’3. Pick vegetables
   409â†’4. Cook in bulk
   410â†’5. Store in containers
   411â†’6. Eat throughout week
   412â†’
   413â†’**Simple Prep (Sunday, 2 hours):**
   414â†’
   415â†’**Proteins:**
   416â†’- 2 lbs chicken breast (baked or grilled)
   417â†’- 1 lb ground turkey or lean beef
   418â†’- 1 dozen hard boiled eggs
   419â†’
   420â†’**Carbs:**

   422â†’- Bag of potatoes (roasted or boiled)
   423â†’- Oats (just need measuring)
   424â†’
   425â†’**Vegetables:**
   426â†’- Pre-washed salad bags
   427â†’- Broccoli/green beans (steam or roast)
   428â†’- Frozen vegetables (microwave)
   429â†’
   430â†’**Assembly:**
   431â†’Each meal: 6-8oz protein + 1 cup carbs + vegetables
   432â†’
   433â†’**If You Hate Meal Prep:**
   434â†’- Buy pre-cooked rotisserie chicken
   435â†’- Microwave rice packets

   437â†’- More expensive but still works
   438â†’

   444â†’- It's not that complicated`,
   445â†’      media: [
   446â†’        {
   447â†’          id: 'meal-prep',
   448â†’          type: 'image',
   449â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532768778661-1b2b2df1d79d?w=800&q=80',
   450â†’          alt: 'Meal prep containers',
   451â†’          caption: 'Meal prep: 2 hours saves you all week',
   452â†’          placement: 'inline',
   453â†’        },
   454â†’      ],
   455â†’    },
   456â†’    {
   457â†’      id: 'common-mistakes',
   458â†’      title: 'Common Nutrition Mistakes',
   459â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   460â†’      content: `Don't be this guy:
   461â†’
   462â†’**Mistake 1: Not Tracking**
   463â†’"I eat healthy but can't lose weight."
   464â†’You're eating more than you think. Track for 2 weeks. I promise.
   465â†’
   466â†’**Mistake 2: Drinking Calories**
   467â†’Soda, juice, alcohol, fancy coffee drinks. 500+ invisible calories daily. Switch to water, black coffee, diet drinks.
   468â†’
   469â†’**Mistake 3: Weekend Destruction**
   470â†’5 days of deficit, 2 days of surplus = maintenance. The weekend counts.
   471â†’
   472â†’**Mistake 4: All-or-Nothing**
   473â†’One bad meal doesn't ruin the week. Just get back on track. Don't spiral into "I already messed up so..."
   474â†’
   475â†’**Mistake 5: Avoiding Carbs**
   476â†’Carbs aren't the enemy. Excess calories are. Low carb works by reducing calories, not magic.
   477â†’
   478â†’**Mistake 6: Not Eating Enough Protein**
   479â†’"I think I get enough." You probably don't. Track it. 0.8-1g/lb is more than most people think.
   480â†’
   481â†’**Mistake 7: Relying on Supplements**
   482â†’No supplement will fix a bad diet. Food first, supplements for gaps.
   483â†’
   484â†’**Mistake 8: Overcomplicating**
   485â†’Meal timing, food combining, "clean eating" obsession. Hit calories and protein. That's 80% of it.`,
   486â†’    },
   487â†’    {
   488â†’      id: 'action-plan',
   489â†’      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   490â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   491â†’      content: `Here's exactly what to do:
   492â†’
   493â†’**Week 1: Baseline**

   495â†’- Get a food scale
   496â†’- Track everything you eat for 7 days (no changes)
   497â†’- See where you actually are
   498â†’
   499â†’**Week 2: Adjust**
   500â†’- Calculate your calorie target based on goal
   501â†’- Set protein target (0.8-1g/lb)
   502â†’- Start hitting these targets
   503â†’
   504â†’**Week 3-4: Dial In**
   505â†’- Monitor weight trends
   506â†’- Adjust calories if needed (not losing? Reduce by 100-200)
   507â†’- Find meals that work for you
   508â†’- Build a rotation of go-to meals

   510â†’**Ongoing: Optimize**

   512â†’- Meal prep to stay consistent

   514â†’- Don't overcomplicate
   515â†’
   516â†’**The Truth:**
   517â†’Most of your results come from:
   518â†’1. Eating in the right calorie range
   519â†’2. Hitting protein consistently
   520â†’3. Doing this for months/years
   521â†’
   522â†’Everything else is optimization. Master these three first.`,
   523â†’      products: ['food_scale'],
   524â†’    },
   525â†’  ],
   526â†’};

<system-reminder>

/**
 * Diet & Nutrition Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const dietGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'diet',
  slug: 'diet-nutrition',
  title: 'Diet & Nutrition',
  subtitle: "You can't out-train a bad diet",
  description: "The fundamentals of eating for aesthetics. Protein, calories, and what actually matters vs what doesn't.",
  icon: 'Utensils',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 15,
  order: 8,
  tags: ['nutrition', 'diet', 'protein', 'calories', 'macros'],
  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'v-taper'],
  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'collagen_peptides', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate'],
  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'diet-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1490645935967-10de6ba17061?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Healthy meal prep and nutrition',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Foundation of Everything',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your physique is built in the kitchen, revealed in the gym.

You can train perfectly, but if your nutrition is garbage:
- You won't build muscle efficiently
- You won't lose fat predictably
- You'll look the same in 6 months

**The Good News:**
Nutrition is simpler than the internet makes it seem. Most of the complexity is unnecessary.

**What Actually Matters (80% of results):**
1. Total calories (energy balance)
2. Protein intake
3. Food quality (mostly)
4. Consistency

**What Barely Matters (20% optimization):**
- Meal timing
- Specific food choices within reason
- Supplement stacks beyond basics
- Nutrient timing around workouts

Let's cover the 80% first.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'diet-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1498837167922-ddd27525d352?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Healthy food and nutrition',
          caption: 'Your physique is built in the kitchen',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'calories',
      title: 'Calories: The Master Variable',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Everything else is secondary to energy balance.

**The Basic Math:**
- Calories In > Calories Out = Weight Gain
- Calories In < Calories Out = Weight Loss
- Calories In = Calories Out = Maintenance

**Finding Your Maintenance:**
Method 1: Calculator estimate
- TDEE calculator gives starting point
- Typically 14-17 x bodyweight (in lbs)
- Active people higher, sedentary lower

Method 2: Track and observe
- Eat the same for 2 weeks
- Track weight daily, average weekly
- Stable = maintenance. Rising = surplus. Dropping = deficit.

**Setting Your Target:**

| Goal | Calorie Target |
|------|---------------|
| Fat Loss | Maintenance - 300-500 |
| Maintenance | TDEE |
| Lean Bulk | Maintenance + 200-300 |
| Standard Bulk | Maintenance + 400-500 |

**The Mistake:**
Going too aggressive. A 1000 calorie deficit sounds fast but leads to muscle loss, metabolic adaptation, and binges. Slow and steady wins.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
      tips: [
        'Use a food scale for accuracyâ€”eyeballing is notoriously wrong',
        'Track for 2-4 weeks to learn your foods, then you can estimate',
        'Weekly average matters more than daily fluctuations'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'protein',
      title: 'Protein: The King of Macros',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `If you remember one thing from this guide: hit your protein.

**Why Protein Is King:**
- Builds and preserves muscle
- Most satiating macro (keeps you full)
- Highest thermic effect (burns calories to digest)
- Hardest to store as fat

**How Much:**
- Minimum: 0.7g per pound of bodyweight
- Optimal: 0.8-1g per pound of bodyweight
- Upper limit: More than 1.2g/lb has no additional benefit

**For a 180lb Guy:**
- Minimum: 126g daily
- Optimal: 144-180g daily

**Best Protein Sources:**

| Source | Protein per 100g |
|--------|-----------------|
| Chicken breast | 31g |
| Lean beef | 26g |
| Salmon | 25g |
| Greek yogurt | 10g |
| Eggs | 13g |
| Cottage cheese | 11g |
| Whey protein | 80g |

**Hitting It Daily:**
- Each meal should have a protein source
- 30-50g per meal, 3-4 meals
- Fill gaps with protein shakes if needed
- Front-load protein earlier in day for satiety`,
    },
    {
      id: 'carbs-fats',
      title: 'Carbs and Fats: The Flexible Macros',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `After calories and protein, carbs and fats are flexible. Here's how to think about them:

**Fats: The Minimum**
- Never go below 0.3g/lb bodyweight
- Fats are essential for hormones (testosterone)
- Too low = hormone problems, brain fog, bad skin
- For 180lb: minimum 54g fat daily

**Carbs: The Performance Fuel**
- Not "essential" but highly beneficial for training
- Fill remaining calories after protein and fat
- More carbs = better gym performance
- Lower carbs = some people do better for fat loss

**Setting Macros (Example: 180lb guy, 2500 calories)**

Option 1: Moderate carb (recommended)
- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
- Fat: 80g (720 cal)
- Carbs: 265g (1060 cal)

Option 2: Lower carb
- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
- Fat: 100g (900 cal)
- Carbs: 220g (880 cal)

Option 3: Higher carb (athletic)
- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
- Fat: 60g (540 cal)
- Carbs: 310g (1240 cal)

**The Truth:**
For most people, the exact ratio doesn't matter much. Hit protein, stay in your calorie range, and adjust carbs/fats based on preference and how you feel.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'food-quality',
      title: 'Food Quality: What to Actually Eat',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Here's where things get simpler than the internet suggests:

**The 80/20 Rule:**
- 80% whole, minimally processed foods
- 20% whatever you want

This keeps you sane while getting results.

**Whole Foods (Prioritize These):**

**Proteins:**
- Chicken, turkey, lean beef, fish
- Eggs, Greek yogurt, cottage cheese
- Whey/casein protein powder

**Carbs:**
- Rice, potatoes, oats
- Fruits, vegetables
- Whole grain bread/pasta

**Fats:**
- Olive oil, avocados
- Nuts, seeds
- Fatty fish (salmon)
- Eggs

**Minimize (Not Eliminate):**
- Fried foods
- Sugary snacks and drinks
- Processed meats regularly
- Alcohol (empty calories + lowers testosterone + disrupts sleep)

**The Why:**
Whole foods are more filling per calorie, have more micronutrients, and are harder to overeat. You can lose weight on junk food (calories are calories), but you'll be hungrier and less healthy.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'whole-foods',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1512621776951-a57141f2eefd?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Whole foods and vegetables',
          caption: '80% whole foods, 20% whatever you want',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'meal-structure',
      title: 'Meal Structure and Timing',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Meal timing is overrated for results but matters for adherence and performance.

**The Basics:**
- Total daily intake matters more than timing
- 3-5 meals per day works for most people
- Don't overthink it

**What Slightly Matters:**

1. **Pre-Workout (1-2 hours before)**
   - Carbs + protein = better performance
   - Don't train completely fasted if you can help it
   - Something > nothing

2. **Post-Workout (within 2-3 hours)**
   - Protein helps start recovery
   - The "anabolic window" is way longer than old bro-science claimed
   - Just eat normally, don't stress

3. **Before Bed**
   - Casein or slow protein can help overnight recovery
   - Not essential, just nice

**A Simple Day Structure:**

- Breakfast: Protein + carbs + fats
- Lunch: Protein + carbs + vegetables
- Pre-workout: Light carbs + protein if needed
- Dinner: Protein + carbs + vegetables
- Optional snack: Protein if needed to hit target

**Intermittent Fasting:**
Some people like it. It doesn't burn more fat, but it can help control calories if you're bad at small meals. Personal preference.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'cutting',
      title: 'Eating for Fat Loss',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `When cutting, everything matters a bit more:

**The Setup:**
1. Calculate maintenance calories
2. Subtract 300-500 calories
3. Set protein at 1g/lb (higher end when cutting)
4. Fill remaining with carbs and fats

**Maximizing Satiety:**
- High volume, low calorie foods (vegetables, lean proteins)
- More protein = more fullness
- High fiber foods
- Drink water before meals
- Eat slowly

**Volume Eating Foods:**
| Food | Calories per 100g |
|------|------------------|
| Lettuce | 5 |
| Cucumber | 16 |
| Egg whites | 52 |
| Chicken breast | 165 |
| Potatoes (boiled) | 77 |
| Greek yogurt (0%) | 59 |

You can eat 500g of potatoes for the same calories as 50g of chips. Volume matters.

**Cutting Mistakes:**
1. Going too aggressive (muscle loss, rebound)
2. Cutting protein (preserves muscle)
3. Eliminating carbs entirely (tanks performance)
4. Weekend binges (erases weekly deficit)
5. Not tracking (guessing incorrectly)`,
      tips: [
        'Weigh daily, average weeklyâ€”weight fluctuates',
        "0.5-1% of bodyweight loss per week is optimal",
        'Hunger is normal but not unbearableâ€”adjust if miserable'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'bulking',
      title: 'Eating for Muscle Gain',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Bulking done right builds muscle. Bulking done wrong just makes you fat.

**The Setup:**
1. Calculate maintenance
2. Add 200-300 calories (lean bulk) or 400-500 (standard bulk)
3. Set protein at 0.8-1g/lb
4. Distribute remaining to carbs and fats (favor carbs for training)

**Lean Bulk vs Dirty Bulk:**

| Approach | Surplus | Result |
|----------|---------|--------|
| Lean bulk | +200-300 | Slow muscle gain, minimal fat |
| Standard bulk | +400-500 | Good muscle gain, some fat |
| Dirty bulk | +1000+ | Some muscle, lots of fat |

**Recommendation:**
Lean bulk unless you're very underweight. Gaining fat doesn't build muscle faster, it just means a longer cut later.

**Weight Gain Rate:**
- Beginners: 2-4 lbs/month possible
- Intermediate: 1-2 lbs/month realistic
- Advanced: 0.5-1 lb/month if lucky

**If weight isn't going up:**
You're not eating enough. Track more accurately and add 100-200 calories.

**Bulking Mistakes:**
1. Gaining too fast ("I'll cut later" â†’ never cuts)
2. Dirty bulking (just makes you fat)
3. Not tracking (surplus might actually be deficit)
4. Using bulk as excuse to eat garbage`,
    },
    {
      id: 'supplements',
      title: 'Supplements That Actually Work',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Most supplements are garbage. Here's what's worth your money:

**Tier 1: Actually Works**

1. **Creatine Monohydrate**
   - 5g daily, any time
   - Strength, size, cognition
   - Costs $0.10/day
   - No loading needed

2. **Protein Powder**
   - Convenient protein source
   - Whey, casein, or plant-based
   - Not magic, just food in powder form

3. **Vitamin D3**
   - Most people are deficient
   - 2000-5000 IU daily
   - Get blood work to confirm

4. **Omega-3 (Fish Oil)**
   - Anti-inflammatory
   - Brain and heart health
   - 2-3g EPA/DHA daily

**Tier 2: Situationally Useful**

5. **Caffeine** â€” Performance boost (from coffee is fine)
6. **Magnesium** â€” Most people are deficient, helps sleep
7. **Collagen** â€” May help joints and skin
8. **Zinc** â€” If deficient (many are)

**Tier 3: Probably Wasting Money**

- BCAAs (get protein instead)
- Fat burners (mostly caffeine + fillers)
- Testosterone boosters (don't work)
- Most pre-workouts (caffeine + expensive pixie dust)

**The Rule:**
Get 95% of results from food. Use supplements to fill gaps, not replace meals.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate', 'collagen_peptides'],
    },
    {
      id: 'practical',
      title: 'Practical Meal Prep',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Knowing what to eat is useless if you don't actually do it. Here's how:

**The Basics of Meal Prep:**
1. Pick 2-3 protein sources
2. Pick 2-3 carb sources
3. Pick vegetables
4. Cook in bulk
5. Store in containers
6. Eat throughout week

**Simple Prep (Sunday, 2 hours):**

**Proteins:**
- 2 lbs chicken breast (baked or grilled)
- 1 lb ground turkey or lean beef
- 1 dozen hard boiled eggs

**Carbs:**
- Big batch of rice (rice cooker)
- Bag of potatoes (roasted or boiled)
- Oats (just need measuring)

**Vegetables:**
- Pre-washed salad bags
- Broccoli/green beans (steam or roast)
- Frozen vegetables (microwave)

**Assembly:**
Each meal: 6-8oz protein + 1 cup carbs + vegetables

**If You Hate Meal Prep:**
- Buy pre-cooked rotisserie chicken
- Microwave rice packets
- Pre-cut vegetables
- More expensive but still works

**Eating Out:**
- Prioritize protein (grilled chicken, fish, steak)
- Ask for dressing on side
- Skip the bread basket
- Don't drink calories
- It's not that complicated`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'meal-prep',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532768778661-1b2b2df1d79d?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Meal prep containers',
          caption: 'Meal prep: 2 hours saves you all week',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'common-mistakes',
      title: 'Common Nutrition Mistakes',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Don't be this guy:

**Mistake 1: Not Tracking**
"I eat healthy but can't lose weight."
You're eating more than you think. Track for 2 weeks. I promise.

**Mistake 2: Drinking Calories**
Soda, juice, alcohol, fancy coffee drinks. 500+ invisible calories daily. Switch to water, black coffee, diet drinks.

**Mistake 3: Weekend Destruction**
5 days of deficit, 2 days of surplus = maintenance. The weekend counts.

**Mistake 4: All-or-Nothing**
One bad meal doesn't ruin the week. Just get back on track. Don't spiral into "I already messed up so..."

**Mistake 5: Avoiding Carbs**
Carbs aren't the enemy. Excess calories are. Low carb works by reducing calories, not magic.

**Mistake 6: Not Eating Enough Protein**
"I think I get enough." You probably don't. Track it. 0.8-1g/lb is more than most people think.

**Mistake 7: Relying on Supplements**
No supplement will fix a bad diet. Food first, supplements for gaps.

**Mistake 8: Overcomplicating**
Meal timing, food combining, "clean eating" obsession. Hit calories and protein. That's 80% of it.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's exactly what to do:

**Week 1: Baseline**
- Download a tracking app (MyFitnessPal, Cronometer)
- Get a food scale
- Track everything you eat for 7 days (no changes)
- See where you actually are

**Week 2: Adjust**
- Calculate your calorie target based on goal
- Set protein target (0.8-1g/lb)
- Start hitting these targets

**Week 3-4: Dial In**
- Monitor weight trends
- Adjust calories if needed (not losing? Reduce by 100-200)
- Find meals that work for you
- Build a rotation of go-to meals

**Ongoing: Optimize**
- Track until you can estimate accurately
- Meal prep to stay consistent
- Weigh weekly, adjust as needed
- Don't overcomplicate

**The Truth:**
Most of your results come from:
1. Eating in the right calorie range
2. Hitting protein consistently
3. Doing this for months/years

Everything else is optimization. Master these three first.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
    },
  ],
};

    38â†’      title: 'The Basics of Good Skin',
    39â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    40â†’      content: `Your skin is literally your face. It's the first thing people see, and it significantly impacts how attractive you appear.
    41â†’
    42â†’**The Good News:**
    43â†’- Skincare is not complicated
    44â†’- Most improvements come from basics
    45â†’- Results happen in weeks to months
    46â†’- It's not expensive
    47â†’
    48â†’**The Bad News:**
    49â†’- Genetics play a role

    51â†’- There are no overnight fixes
    52â†’- Consistency is required
    53â†’
    54â†’**What Actually Works:**

    57â†’3. Sunscreen (prevent damage)

    70â†’2. Apply moisturizer
    71â†’3. Apply sunscreen (non-negotiable)
    72â†’
    73â†’**Evening Routine (3 minutes):**
    74â†’1. Cleanse face (remove dirt, oil, sunscreen)
    75â†’2. Apply any actives (tretinoin, etc.)
    76â†’3. Apply moisturizer
    77â†’
    78â†’**That's It.**
    79â†’
    80â†’Don't overcomplicate. Don't buy 10 products because TikTok said so. The basic routine done consistently beats a 12-step routine done sporadically.
    81â†’
    82â†’**Order Matters:**
    83â†’Thinnest to thickest consistency:
    84â†’1. Cleansers (remove)
    85â†’2. Toners/serums (watery actives)
    86â†’3. Treatments (tretinoin, etc.)
    87â†’4. Moisturizer (seal it in)
    88â†’5. Sunscreen (protect from sun)`,

    94â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    95â†’      content: `Most guys either skip cleansing or do it wrong.
    96â†’
    97â†’**The Goal:**
    98â†’Remove dirt, oil, sweat, and sunscreen without stripping your skin.
    99â†’
   100â†’**How to Cleanse:**
   101â†’1. Wet face with lukewarm water (not hot)
   102â†’2. Apply dime-sized amount of cleanser
   103â†’3. Massage gently for 30-60 seconds
   104â†’4. Rinse thoroughly
   105â†’5. Pat dry (don't rub)
   106â†’
   107â†’**Choosing a Cleanser:**
   108â†’
   109â†’| Skin Type | Cleanser Type |
   110â†’|-----------|---------------|
   111â†’| Oily/Acne | Foaming/gel cleanser |
   112â†’| Normal | Either works |
   113â†’| Dry/Sensitive | Cream/hydrating cleanser |
   114â†’
   115â†’**Recommended:** CeraVe Foaming (oily) or CeraVe Hydrating (dry)
   116â†’
   117â†’**Common Mistakes:**
   118â†’1. Over-cleansing (2x daily max)
   119â†’2. Hot water (damages barrier)
   120â†’3. Harsh scrubs (causes irritation)
   121â†’4. Not rinsing fully (leaves residue)
   122â†’5. Rubbing with towel (causes friction)
   123â†’
   124â†’**The Feel:**
   125â†’After cleansing, skin should feel clean but not tight or squeaky. If it feels stripped, your cleanser is too harsh.`,

   138â†’    {
   139â†’      id: 'moisturizing',
   140â†’      title: 'Moisturizing: Seal It In',
   141â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   142â†’      content: `A healthy skin barrier is the foundation of good skin.
   143â†’
   144â†’**Why Moisturize:**
   145â†’- Prevents water loss
   146â†’- Repairs barrier function
   147â†’- Reduces sensitivity
   148â†’- Makes skin look healthier
   149â†’- Required if using actives like tretinoin
   150â†’
   151â†’**When:**
   152â†’- Morning (after cleansing, before sunscreen)
   153â†’- Evening (after actives or as last step)
   154â†’
   155â†’**Choosing a Moisturizer:**
   156â†’
   157â†’| Skin Type | Texture |
   158â†’|-----------|---------|
   159â†’| Oily | Lightweight/gel moisturizer |
   160â†’| Normal | Lotion texture |
   161â†’| Dry | Cream texture |
   162â†’
   163â†’**Recommended:** CeraVe PM (lightweight), CeraVe Cream (thicker)
   164â†’
   165â†’**Key Ingredients to Look For:**
   166â†’- Ceramides (barrier repair)
   167â†’- Hyaluronic acid (hydration)
   168â†’- Niacinamide (reduces pores, calms skin)
   169â†’- Glycerin (hydration)
   170â†’
   171â†’**Application:**
   172â†’- Apply to slightly damp skin for better absorption
   173â†’- Use enough to cover face without being greasy
   174â†’- Don't forget neck`,
   175â†’      products: ['cerave_moisturizer'],
   176â†’    },
   177â†’    {
   178â†’      id: 'sunscreen',
   179â†’      title: 'Sunscreen: The Anti-Aging Essential',
   180â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   181â†’      content: `Sun damage is the biggest scam your skin is running on your future self. Block it.
   182â†’
   183â†’**The Reality:**
   184â†’- 80% of visible skin aging is from sun exposure
   185â†’- UV damage accumulates over years
   186â†’- By the time you see damage, it's already been happening for a decade
   187â†’- Sunscreen is the #1 anti-aging product
   188â†’
   189â†’**The Protocol:**
   190â†’- SPF 30 minimum, SPF 50 preferred
   191â†’- Apply every morning (yes, even cloudy days)
   192â†’- Reapply every 2 hours if outdoors
   193â†’- About 1/4 teaspoon for face
   194â†’
   195â†’**Choosing Sunscreen:**
   196â†’
   197â†’**Chemical Sunscreens:**
   198â†’- Absorbs into skin, absorbs UV rays
   199â†’- More cosmetically elegant
   200â†’- May sting eyes or irritate some skin
   201â†’- Examples: Avobenzone, oxybenzone, octinoxate
   202â†’
   203â†’**Mineral Sunscreens:**
   204â†’- Sits on skin, reflects UV rays
   205â†’- Can leave white cast
   206â†’- Better for sensitive skin
   207â†’- Examples: Zinc oxide, titanium dioxide
   208â†’
   209â†’**Recommended:** EltaMD UV Clear SPF 46 (best for acne-prone skin)
   210â†’
   211â†’**The Excuses (And Why They're Wrong):**
   212â†’- "I don't burn" â†’ UV damage happens regardless
   213â†’- "I'm indoors" â†’ UVA goes through windows
   214â†’- "It's cloudy" â†’ 80% of UV penetrates clouds
   215â†’- "Sunscreen causes acne" â†’ Get a better sunscreen`,
   216â†’      products: ['sunscreen_elta'],

   221â†’      media: [
