   232â†’    {
   233â†’      id: 'acne',
   234â†’      title: 'Acne: Understanding and Treating',
   235â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   236â†’      content: `Acne is the most common skin concern. Here's how to actually treat it.
   237â†’
   238â†’**What Causes Acne:**
   239â†’1. Excess sebum (oil) production
   240â†’2. Dead skin cells clogging pores
   241â†’3. Bacteria (C. acnes)
   242â†’4. Inflammation
   243â†’
   244â†’**Types of Acne:**
   245â†’- **Comedonal:** Blackheads and whiteheads (clogged pores)
   246â†’- **Inflammatory:** Red, swollen pimples
   247â†’- **Cystic:** Deep, painful, scarring
   248â†’
   249â†’**Treatment Hierarchy:**
   250â†’
   251â†’**Level 1: Basic Routine**
   252â†’- Consistent cleansing
   253â†’- Non-comedogenic moisturizer
   254â†’- Often fixes mild acne
   255â†’
   256â†’**Level 2: Over-the-Counter Actives**
   257â†’- Benzoyl peroxide (kills bacteria)
   258â†’- Salicylic acid (unclogs pores)
   259â†’- Adapalene/Differin (retinoid, OTC)
   260â†’
   261â†’**Level 3: Prescription**
   262â†’- Tretinoin (see next section)
   263â†’- Antibiotics (temporary)
   264â†’- Spironolactone (hormonal, for women)
   265â†’
   266â†’**Level 4: Accutane/Isotretinoin**
   267â†’- Nuclear option for severe or resistant acne
   268â†’- 4-6 month course, usually permanent results
   269â†’- Side effects but highly effective
   270â†’- Requires dermatologist
   271â†’
   272â†’**General Rules:**
   273â†’- Be patient (6-12 weeks for actives to work)
   274â†’- Don't pick (causes scarring)
   275â†’- Change pillowcase frequently
   276â†’- Clean phone screen`,
   277â†’    },
   278â†’    {
   279â†’      id: 'tretinoin',
   280â†’      title: 'Tretinoin: The Gold Standard',
   281â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   282â†’      content: `Tretinoin (prescription retinoid) is the most evidence-backed skincare ingredient for both acne and anti-aging.
   283â†’
   284â†’**What It Does:**
   285â†’- Increases cell turnover
   286â†’- Unclogs pores
   287â†’- Reduces acne
   288â†’- Fades dark spots
   289â†’- Reduces fine lines
   290â†’- Improves skin texture
   291â†’
   292â†’**How to Get It:**
   293â†’- Dermatologist prescription
   294â†’- Online telemedicine (Curology, Apostrophe)
   295â†’- Some countries: OTC
   296â†’
   297â†’**Starting Protocol (Critical):**
   298â†’
   299â†’**Week 1-2:** 2x per week only
   300â†’**Week 3-4:** Every other night
   301â†’**Week 5-6:** Every night (if tolerated)
   302â†’**Ongoing:** Nightly, thin layer
   303â†’
   304â†’**The Retinization Period:**
   305â†’Expect 4-12 weeks of:
   306â†’- Dryness
   307â†’- Peeling
   308â†’- Redness
   309â†’- Possible purging (temporary increase in acne)
   310â†’
   311â†’This is normal. Push through carefully. It gets better.
   312â†’
   313â†’**Application Tips:**
   314â†’1. Apply to completely dry skin (wait 20 min after washing)
   315â†’2. Pea-sized amount for entire face
   316â†’3. Avoid eye area initially
   317â†’4. Follow with moisturizer
   318â†’5. Use sunscreen daily (skin is more sensitive)
   319â†’
   320â†’**Don't Use With:**
   321â†’- Benzoyl peroxide (inactivates tret)
   322â†’- Vitamin C (morning only)
   323â†’- Other strong actives initially
   324â†’
   325â†’**The Payoff:**
   326â†’12-month mark is where the magic happens. Consistent tretinoin use genuinely reverses aging and transforms skin.`,
   327â†’      products: ['tretinoin_guide', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
   328â†’      warnings: [
   329â†’        'Start low and slowâ€”0.025% is enough initially',
   330â†’        'Over-application causes more irritation, not faster results',
   331â†’        'Tretinoin + sun exposure = damage. Always use sunscreen.'
   332â†’      ],
   333â†’      media: [
   334â†’        {
   335â†’          id: 'tretinoin-application',
   336â†’          type: 'image',
   337â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1620916566398-39f1143ab7be?w=800&q=80',

   341â†’        },
   342â†’        {
   343â†’          id: 'tretinoin-timeline',
   344â†’          type: 'image',
   345â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598440947619-2c35fc9aa908?w=800&q=80',
   346â†’          alt: 'Skincare progress and results',

   348â†’          placement: 'full-width',
   349â†’        },
   350â†’      ],
   351â†’    },
   352â†’    {
   353â†’      id: 'skin-type',
   354â†’      title: 'Know Your Skin Type',
   355â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   356â†’      content: `Your skin type determines product selection.
   357â†’
   358â†’**Oily Skin:**
   359â†’- Shiny by midday
   360â†’- Visible pores
   361â†’- Prone to acne
   362â†’- Needs: Gel cleansers, lightweight moisturizers, mattifying products
   363â†’
   364â†’**Dry Skin:**
   365â†’- Feels tight
   366â†’- Flaking or rough texture
   367â†’- Fine lines more visible
   368â†’- Needs: Cream cleansers, rich moisturizers, hydrating ingredients
   369â†’
   370â†’**Combination Skin:**
   371â†’- Oily T-zone (forehead, nose, chin)
   372â†’- Dry cheeks
   373â†’- Most common type
   374â†’- Needs: Balanced approach, zone-specific treatment
   375â†’
   376â†’**Sensitive Skin:**
   377â†’- Reacts easily to products
   378â†’- Redness, stinging
   379â†’- Needs: Fragrance-free, minimal ingredients, patch testing
   380â†’
   381â†’**Normal Skin:**
   382â†’- Balanced
   383â†’- Few issues
   384â†’- Needs: Basic maintenance
   385â†’
   386â†’**How to Test:**
   387â†’1. Wash face, wait 30 minutes
   388â†’2. Don't apply anything
   389â†’3. Observe how skin feels and looks
   390â†’
   391â†’If shiny â†’ oily
   392â†’If tight â†’ dry
   393â†’If both â†’ combination
   394â†’If irritated â†’ sensitive
   395â†’If fine â†’ normal`,
   396â†’    },
   397â†’    {
   398â†’      id: 'acne-scarring',
   399â†’      title: 'Acne Scars: What Actually Works',
   400â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   401â†’      content: `Once acne is controlled, scars may remain. Here's what helps:
   402â†’
   403â†’**Types of Acne Scars:**
   404â†’- **Icepick:** Deep, narrow, V-shaped
   405â†’- **Boxcar:** Wide, box-like depressions
   406â†’- **Rolling:** Wave-like, uneven surface
   407â†’- **Hyperpigmentation:** Dark marks (not true scars)
   408â†’
   409â†’**What Actually Works:**
   410â†’
   411â†’**For Hyperpigmentation (Dark Marks):**
   412â†’- Time (fades naturally in 3-12 months)
   413â†’- Tretinoin (speeds fading)
   414â†’- Vitamin C (morning antioxidant)
   415â†’- Niacinamide (in moisturizer)
   416â†’- Sunscreen (prevents darkening)
   417â†’
   418â†’**For True Scars (Texture):**
   419â†’- Tretinoin (mild improvement over years)
   420â†’- Microneedling (professional, 4-6 sessions)
   421â†’- Chemical peels (professional, multiple sessions)
   422â†’- Laser resurfacing (fractional CO2 or Fraxel)
   423â†’- Subcision (for tethered scars)
   424â†’- TCA Cross (for icepick scars)
   425â†’
   426â†’**The Reality:**
   427â†’- OTC products can't fix true textural scars
   428â†’- Professional treatments are needed
   429â†’- Multiple sessions required
   430â†’- Results are improvement, not perfection
   431â†’- Cost: $200-500+ per session
   432â†’
   433â†’**Priority:**
   434â†’1. Get acne under control first (stop creating new scars)
   435â†’2. Wait for active breakouts to clear
   436â†’3. Then address scarring`,
   437â†’    },
   438â†’    {
   439â†’      id: 'lifestyle-factors',
   440â†’      title: 'Lifestyle Factors for Clear Skin',
   441â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   442â†’      content: `Your routine matters, but so does everything else:
   443â†’
   444â†’**Sleep:**
   445â†’- 7-9 hours for skin repair
   446â†’- Poor sleep = inflammation = worse skin
   447â†’- Sleep on clean pillowcases (change 2x/week)
   448â†’- Silk pillowcase reduces friction
   449â†’
   450â†’**Diet:**
   451â†’- High glycemic foods may worsen acne
   452â†’- Dairy is problematic for some people
   453â†’- Stay hydrated (not magic, but helps)
   454â†’- Omega-3s (anti-inflammatory)
   455â†’
   456â†’**Stress:**
   457â†’- Cortisol triggers oil production
   458â†’- Stress acne is real
   459â†’- Manage what you can
   460â†’
   461â†’**Habits:**
   462â†’- Don't touch your face
   463â†’- Clean your phone
   464â†’- Wash pillowcases
   465â†’- Don't pick at skin
   466â†’- Remove makeup before bed
   467â†’
   468â†’**Gym:**

   470â†’- Wipe face during workout
   471â†’- Shower/cleanse after
   472â†’- Don't use dirty towels on face
   473â†’
   474â†’**Sun:**
   475â†’- Some sun can temporarily help acne
   476â†’- But UV damage is worse long-term
   477â†’- Use sunscreen anyway`,
   478â†’    },
   479â†’    {
   480â†’      id: 'routine-by-goal',
   481â†’      title: 'Routines by Goal',
   482â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   483â†’      content: `Customize based on your primary concern:
   484â†’
   485â†’**Goal: Basic Maintenance (No Issues)**
   486â†’- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
   487â†’- PM: Cleanse, moisturize
   488â†’
   489â†’**Goal: Acne Control**
   490â†’- AM: Cleanse, moisturize, sunscreen
   491â†’- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin (or benzoyl peroxide), moisturize
   492â†’
   493â†’**Goal: Anti-Aging**
   494â†’- AM: Cleanse, vitamin C serum, moisturize, sunscreen
   495â†’- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin, moisturize
   496â†’

   498â†’- AM: Foaming cleanser, lightweight moisturizer, mattifying sunscreen
   499â†’- PM: Foaming cleanser, niacinamide serum, lightweight moisturizer
   500â†’

   504â†’- Add actives very slowly
   505â†’
   506â†’**Remember:**
   507â†’Start with basics. Add one product at a time. Wait 2-4 weeks between additions. This lets you identify what works and what causes problems.`,
   508â†’    },
   509â†’    {
   510â†’      id: 'action-plan',
   511â†’      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   512â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   513â†’      content: `Here's your step-by-step skincare implementation:
   514â†’
   515â†’**Week 1-2: Basics Only**
   516â†’- Buy: Cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen
   517â†’- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen

   524â†’- Identify primary concern (acne, aging, etc.)
   525â†’
   526â†’**Month 2: Add One Active**
   527â†’- For acne: Start benzoyl peroxide OR tretinoin (not both)
   528â†’- For aging: Start tretinoin OR vitamin C (pick one)
   529â†’- Add slowly (2-3x/week first)
   530â†’
   531â†’**Month 3-6: Build and Maintain**
   532â†’- Increase frequency of actives as tolerated
   533â†’- Full tretinoin use (nightly) if pursuing
   534â†’- Evaluate progress monthly
   535â†’
   536â†’**Ongoing: Consistency**
   537â†’- Routine should take <5 min per session
   538â†’- Results come from months/years of consistency
   539â†’- Don't add new products constantly
   540â†’
   541â†’**Product Recommendations:**
   542â†’- Cleanser: CeraVe Foaming or Hydrating
   543â†’- Moisturizer: CeraVe PM
   544â†’- Sunscreen: EltaMD UV Clear
   545â†’- Retinoid: Tretinoin 0.025% (prescription)
   546â†’
   547â†’This is the evidence-based, no-BS approach. Simple, effective, sustainable.`,

file.content:
/**
 * Skincare & Acne Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const skincareGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'skincare',
  slug: 'skincare-acne',
  title: 'Skincare & Acne',
  subtitle: "Your skin is your face. Treat it right.",
  description: "Evidence-based skincare routines for clear, healthy skin. From basics to advanced treatments like tretinoin.",
  icon: 'Droplet',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 9,
  tags: ['skincare', 'acne', 'anti-aging', 'routine', 'tretinoin'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat', 'diet'],
  productIds: [
    'cerave_cleanser',
    'cerave_moisturizer',
    'sunscreen_elta',
    'aquaphor_lip',
    'tretinoin_guide',
  ],
  forumCategory: 'poor-skin',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'skincare-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1556228720-195a672e8a03?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Clear, healthy skin and skincare',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Basics of Good Skin',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your skin is literally your face. It's the first thing people see, and it significantly impacts how attractive you appear.

**The Good News:**
- Skincare is not complicated
- Most improvements come from basics
- Results happen in weeks to months
- It's not expensive

**The Bad News:**
- Genetics play a role
- Some things take time
- There are no overnight fixes
- Consistency is required

**What Actually Works:**
1. Cleanser (clean skin)
2. Moisturizer (healthy barrier)
3. Sunscreen (prevent damage)
4. Tretinoin (for acne/anti-aging)

That's the core. Everything else is optimization.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine-basics',
      title: 'The Basic Routine',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Start here. Master this before adding anything else.

**Morning Routine (2 minutes):**
1. Rinse face with water (or gentle cleanser if oily)
2. Apply moisturizer
3. Apply sunscreen (non-negotiable)

**Evening Routine (3 minutes):**
1. Cleanse face (remove dirt, oil, sunscreen)
2. Apply any actives (tretinoin, etc.)
3. Apply moisturizer

**That's It.**

Don't overcomplicate. Don't buy 10 products because TikTok said so. The basic routine done consistently beats a 12-step routine done sporadically.

**Order Matters:**
Thinnest to thickest consistency:
1. Cleansers (remove)
2. Toners/serums (watery actives)
3. Treatments (tretinoin, etc.)
4. Moisturizer (seal it in)
5. Sunscreen (protect from sun)`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
    },
    {
      id: 'cleansing',
      title: 'Cleansing: Do It Right',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most guys either skip cleansing or do it wrong.

**The Goal:**
Remove dirt, oil, sweat, and sunscreen without stripping your skin.

**How to Cleanse:**
1. Wet face with lukewarm water (not hot)
2. Apply dime-sized amount of cleanser
3. Massage gently for 30-60 seconds
4. Rinse thoroughly
5. Pat dry (don't rub)

**Choosing a Cleanser:**

| Skin Type | Cleanser Type |
|-----------|---------------|
| Oily/Acne | Foaming/gel cleanser |
| Normal | Either works |
| Dry/Sensitive | Cream/hydrating cleanser |

**Recommended:** CeraVe Foaming (oily) or CeraVe Hydrating (dry)

**Common Mistakes:**
1. Over-cleansing (2x daily max)
2. Hot water (damages barrier)
3. Harsh scrubs (causes irritation)
4. Not rinsing fully (leaves residue)
5. Rubbing with towel (causes friction)

**The Feel:**
After cleansing, skin should feel clean but not tight or squeaky. If it feels stripped, your cleanser is too harsh.`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser'],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'cleansing-technique',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1556228994-6c24d36f2d8e?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Skincare routine and cleansing',
          caption: 'Gentle circular motions for 30-60 seconds',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'moisturizing',
      title: 'Moisturizing: Seal It In',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `A healthy skin barrier is the foundation of good skin.

**Why Moisturize:**
- Prevents water loss
- Repairs barrier function
- Reduces sensitivity
- Makes skin look healthier
- Required if using actives like tretinoin

**When:**
- Morning (after cleansing, before sunscreen)
- Evening (after actives or as last step)

**Choosing a Moisturizer:**

| Skin Type | Texture |
|-----------|---------|
| Oily | Lightweight/gel moisturizer |
| Normal | Lotion texture |
| Dry | Cream texture |

**Recommended:** CeraVe PM (lightweight), CeraVe Cream (thicker)

**Key Ingredients to Look For:**
- Ceramides (barrier repair)
- Hyaluronic acid (hydration)
- Niacinamide (reduces pores, calms skin)
- Glycerin (hydration)

**Application:**
- Apply to slightly damp skin for better absorption
- Use enough to cover face without being greasy
- Don't forget neck`,
      products: ['cerave_moisturizer'],
    },
    {
      id: 'sunscreen',
      title: 'Sunscreen: The Anti-Aging Essential',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Sun damage is the biggest scam your skin is running on your future self. Block it.

**The Reality:**
- 80% of visible skin aging is from sun exposure
- UV damage accumulates over years
- By the time you see damage, it's already been happening for a decade
- Sunscreen is the #1 anti-aging product

**The Protocol:**
- SPF 30 minimum, SPF 50 preferred
- Apply every morning (yes, even cloudy days)
- Reapply every 2 hours if outdoors
- About 1/4 teaspoon for face

**Choosing Sunscreen:**

**Chemical Sunscreens:**
- Absorbs into skin, absorbs UV rays
- More cosmetically elegant
- May sting eyes or irritate some skin
- Examples: Avobenzone, oxybenzone, octinoxate

**Mineral Sunscreens:**
- Sits on skin, reflects UV rays
- Can leave white cast
- Better for sensitive skin
- Examples: Zinc oxide, titanium dioxide

**Recommended:** EltaMD UV Clear SPF 46 (best for acne-prone skin)

**The Excuses (And Why They're Wrong):**
- "I don't burn" â†’ UV damage happens regardless
- "I'm indoors" â†’ UVA goes through windows
- "It's cloudy" â†’ 80% of UV penetrates clouds
- "Sunscreen causes acne" â†’ Get a better sunscreen`,
      products: ['sunscreen_elta'],
      warnings: [
        'Skipping sunscreen will undo your other skincare efforts',
        'Reapply if outdoors for extended periods'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'sunscreen-amount',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532413992378-f169ac26fff0?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Sunscreen and sun protection',
          caption: 'Use about 1/4 teaspoon (two finger lengths) for your face',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'acne',
      title: 'Acne: Understanding and Treating',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Acne is the most common skin concern. Here's how to actually treat it.

**What Causes Acne:**
1. Excess sebum (oil) production
2. Dead skin cells clogging pores
3. Bacteria (C. acnes)
4. Inflammation

**Types of Acne:**
- **Comedonal:** Blackheads and whiteheads (clogged pores)
- **Inflammatory:** Red, swollen pimples
- **Cystic:** Deep, painful, scarring

**Treatment Hierarchy:**

**Level 1: Basic Routine**
- Consistent cleansing
- Non-comedogenic moisturizer
- Often fixes mild acne

**Level 2: Over-the-Counter Actives**
- Benzoyl peroxide (kills bacteria)
- Salicylic acid (unclogs pores)
- Adapalene/Differin (retinoid, OTC)

**Level 3: Prescription**
- Tretinoin (see next section)
- Antibiotics (temporary)
- Spironolactone (hormonal, for women)

**Level 4: Accutane/Isotretinoin**
- Nuclear option for severe or resistant acne
- 4-6 month course, usually permanent results
- Side effects but highly effective
- Requires dermatologist

**General Rules:**
- Be patient (6-12 weeks for actives to work)
- Don't pick (causes scarring)
- Change pillowcase frequently
- Clean phone screen`,
    },
    {
      id: 'tretinoin',
      title: 'Tretinoin: The Gold Standard',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Tretinoin (prescription retinoid) is the most evidence-backed skincare ingredient for both acne and anti-aging.

**What It Does:**
- Increases cell turnover
- Unclogs pores
- Reduces acne
- Fades dark spots
- Reduces fine lines
- Improves skin texture

**How to Get It:**
- Dermatologist prescription
- Online telemedicine (Curology, Apostrophe)
- Some countries: OTC

**Starting Protocol (Critical):**

**Week 1-2:** 2x per week only
**Week 3-4:** Every other night
**Week 5-6:** Every night (if tolerated)
**Ongoing:** Nightly, thin layer

**The Retinization Period:**
Expect 4-12 weeks of:
- Dryness
- Peeling
- Redness
- Possible purging (temporary increase in acne)

This is normal. Push through carefully. It gets better.

**Application Tips:**
1. Apply to completely dry skin (wait 20 min after washing)
2. Pea-sized amount for entire face
3. Avoid eye area initially
4. Follow with moisturizer
5. Use sunscreen daily (skin is more sensitive)

**Don't Use With:**
- Benzoyl peroxide (inactivates tret)
- Vitamin C (morning only)
- Other strong actives initially

**The Payoff:**
12-month mark is where the magic happens. Consistent tretinoin use genuinely reverses aging and transforms skin.`,
      products: ['tretinoin_guide', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
      warnings: [
        'Start low and slowâ€”0.025% is enough initially',
        'Over-application causes more irritation, not faster results',
        'Tretinoin + sun exposure = damage. Always use sunscreen.'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'tretinoin-application',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1620916566398-39f1143ab7be?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Skincare product application',
          caption: 'Pea-sized amount, dot on forehead, cheeks, chin, then spread',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'tretinoin-timeline',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598440947619-2c35fc9aa908?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Skincare progress and results',
          caption: 'Expect 3-6 months for initial improvement, 12+ for full results',
          placement: 'full-width',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'skin-type',
      title: 'Know Your Skin Type',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your skin type determines product selection.

**Oily Skin:**
- Shiny by midday
- Visible pores
- Prone to acne
- Needs: Gel cleansers, lightweight moisturizers, mattifying products

**Dry Skin:**
- Feels tight
- Flaking or rough texture
- Fine lines more visible
- Needs: Cream cleansers, rich moisturizers, hydrating ingredients

**Combination Skin:**
- Oily T-zone (forehead, nose, chin)
- Dry cheeks
- Most common type
- Needs: Balanced approach, zone-specific treatment

**Sensitive Skin:**
- Reacts easily to products
- Redness, stinging
- Needs: Fragrance-free, minimal ingredients, patch testing

**Normal Skin:**
- Balanced
- Few issues
- Needs: Basic maintenance

**How to Test:**
1. Wash face, wait 30 minutes
2. Don't apply anything
3. Observe how skin feels and looks

If shiny â†’ oily
If tight â†’ dry
If both â†’ combination
If irritated â†’ sensitive
If fine â†’ normal`,
    },
    {
      id: 'acne-scarring',
      title: 'Acne Scars: What Actually Works',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Once acne is controlled, scars may remain. Here's what helps:

**Types of Acne Scars:**
- **Icepick:** Deep, narrow, V-shaped
- **Boxcar:** Wide, box-like depressions
- **Rolling:** Wave-like, uneven surface
- **Hyperpigmentation:** Dark marks (not true scars)

**What Actually Works:**

**For Hyperpigmentation (Dark Marks):**
- Time (fades naturally in 3-12 months)
- Tretinoin (speeds fading)
- Vitamin C (morning antioxidant)
- Niacinamide (in moisturizer)
- Sunscreen (prevents darkening)

**For True Scars (Texture):**
- Tretinoin (mild improvement over years)
- Microneedling (professional, 4-6 sessions)
- Chemical peels (professional, multiple sessions)
- Laser resurfacing (fractional CO2 or Fraxel)
- Subcision (for tethered scars)
- TCA Cross (for icepick scars)

**The Reality:**
- OTC products can't fix true textural scars
- Professional treatments are needed
- Multiple sessions required
- Results are improvement, not perfection
- Cost: $200-500+ per session

**Priority:**
1. Get acne under control first (stop creating new scars)
2. Wait for active breakouts to clear
3. Then address scarring`,
    },
    {
      id: 'lifestyle-factors',
      title: 'Lifestyle Factors for Clear Skin',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your routine matters, but so does everything else:

**Sleep:**
- 7-9 hours for skin repair
- Poor sleep = inflammation = worse skin
- Sleep on clean pillowcases (change 2x/week)
- Silk pillowcase reduces friction

**Diet:**
- High glycemic foods may worsen acne
- Dairy is problematic for some people
- Stay hydrated (not magic, but helps)
- Omega-3s (anti-inflammatory)

**Stress:**
- Cortisol triggers oil production
- Stress acne is real
- Manage what you can

**Habits:**
- Don't touch your face
- Clean your phone
- Wash pillowcases
- Don't pick at skin
- Remove makeup before bed

**Gym:**
- Sweat can clog pores
- Wipe face during workout
- Shower/cleanse after
- Don't use dirty towels on face

**Sun:**
- Some sun can temporarily help acne
- But UV damage is worse long-term
- Use sunscreen anyway`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine-by-goal',
      title: 'Routines by Goal',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Customize based on your primary concern:

**Goal: Basic Maintenance (No Issues)**
- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, moisturize

**Goal: Acne Control**
- AM: Cleanse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin (or benzoyl peroxide), moisturize

**Goal: Anti-Aging**
- AM: Cleanse, vitamin C serum, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin, moisturize

**Goal: Oily Skin Control**
- AM: Foaming cleanser, lightweight moisturizer, mattifying sunscreen
- PM: Foaming cleanser, niacinamide serum, lightweight moisturizer

**Goal: Sensitive Skin**
- AM: Water rinse, fragrance-free moisturizer, mineral sunscreen
- PM: Gentle cleanser, fragrance-free moisturizer
- Add actives very slowly

**Remember:**
Start with basics. Add one product at a time. Wait 2-4 weeks between additions. This lets you identify what works and what causes problems.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's your step-by-step skincare implementation:

**Week 1-2: Basics Only**
- Buy: Cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen
- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, moisturize
- Get consistent with this before adding anything

**Week 3-4: Assess and Adjust**
- Is skin tolerating basics well?
- Any reactions to products?
- Identify primary concern (acne, aging, etc.)

**Month 2: Add One Active**
- For acne: Start benzoyl peroxide OR tretinoin (not both)
- For aging: Start tretinoin OR vitamin C (pick one)
- Add slowly (2-3x/week first)

**Month 3-6: Build and Maintain**
- Increase frequency of actives as tolerated
- Full tretinoin use (nightly) if pursuing
- Evaluate progress monthly

**Ongoing: Consistency**
- Routine should take <5 min per session
- Results come from months/years of consistency
- Don't add new products constantly

**Product Recommendations:**
- Cleanser: CeraVe Foaming or Hydrating
- Moisturizer: CeraVe PM
- Sunscreen: EltaMD UV Clear
- Retinoid: Tretinoin 0.025% (prescription)

This is the evidence-based, no-BS approach. Simple, effective, sustainable.`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta', 'tretinoin_guide'],
    },
  ],
};

## Product Integration System

### Multi-Region Affiliate Support

**6 Regions Supported:**
1. **US** - Amazon.com (ASIN: looksmaxx-20)
2. **UK** - Amazon.co.uk (ASIN: looksmaxx-21)
3. **DE** - Amazon.de (ASIN: looksmaxx-21)
4. **FR** - Amazon.fr (ASIN: looksmaxx-21)
5. **AU** - Amazon.com.au (ASIN: looksmaxx-22)
6. **ASIA** - Amzn.asia (ASIN: looksmaxx-22)

### Affiliate Link Resolution Hierarchy (in `src/lib/region.ts`):

1. **User Preference (localStorage)** - Highest priority
2. **Browser Locale** (navigator.language) - en-US â†’ US, de-DE â†’ DE, etc.
3. **Timezone Detection** - Intl.DateTimeFormat() - America/* â†’ US, Europe/London â†’ UK, etc.
4. **Fallback Chain** - AU (widest availability) â†’ US â†’ Direct Link â†’ First available

### ProductCallout Integration:

The guides system links products via:
- **`GuideProduct.regionLinks`** - Maps region to affiliate URL
- **`GuideProduct.directLink`** - Non-Amazon fallback (e.g., tretinoin â†’ goodrx.com, NMN â†’ prohealthlongevity.com)
- **Region-aware pricing** - Products include price ranges that format with correct currency symbol

### How Products Are Referenced in Guides:

**Three integration points:**

1. **Section-level products** - `GuideSection.products[]` - Specific product IDs mentioned in that section
2. **Guide-level products** - `Guide.productIds[]` - All products referenced in guide
3. **Direct section content** - Product names/descriptions embedded in markdown content with links

## Key Implementation Features

### Type System (`src/types/guides.ts`):

- **Guide Interface:** id, slug, title, subtitle, description, icon, humorLevel, estimatedReadTime, sections[], relatedGuides[], productIds[], forumCategory
- **GuideSection:** id, title, content (markdown), humorLevel, products[], tips[], warnings[], media[]
- **GuideProduct:** id, name, brand, category, tagline, description, priority (1-3), priceRange, regionLinks, directLink, imageUrl, isBaseStack
- **GuideMedia:** id, type (gif/image/video), url, alt, caption, placement (inline/hero/full-width)

### Helper Functions Available:

- `getGuideById()` / `getGuideBySlug()`
- `getGuidesByCategory(categoryId)`
- `getRelatedGuides(guideId)`
- `searchGuides(query)`
- `getTotalGuideCount()` / `getTotalReadTime()` - 9 guides, 95 minutes total reading time
- `getGuideProductById()`
- `getGuideProductsByCategory()`
- `getBaseStackProducts()`
- `searchGuideProducts()`

### Region Detection (`src/lib/region.ts`):

**Smart cascading detection:**
```typescript
// 1. Check localStorage for saved preference
// 2. Parse browser language (navigator.language)
// 3. Detect timezone via Intl.DateTimeFormat()
// 4. Continent-based fallback (America/*, Europe/*, etc.)
// 5. Default to 'us'
```

**Link Resolution:**
```typescript
getProductLink(regionLinks, region, directLink)
  â†’ Try requested region
  â†’ Fallback to AU (widest availability)
  â†’ Fallback to US
  â†’ Use direct link
  â†’ Return first available or '#'
```
